Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On a more tempered and focused note I would like to initially reflect on the original goals of the AIDC and where the AIDC is at now. A little later I will speak about the management and board of the AIDC, which the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) raised in his speech in this second reading debate. For the record, AIDC Ltd is now an investment house that provides infrastructure, resources and corporate advice and financing in Australia and Asia. It is a specialist in equity investment and funds management and financial markets and securitisation. The AIDC Sale Bill, which was introduced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), puts in place the commitment of the coalition government in the March 1996 election campaign to privatise AIDC Ltd. The Australian Industry Development Corporation was set up in 1970 as a statutory corporation. Its mission was to facilitate and encourage the establishment, development and advancement of Australian industries. It is fair to say that the AIDC has had some great investsuccesses-for example, the North West Shelf gas project financing for Woodside Petroleum Ltd; the project financing for the massive Eraring power station in New South Wales; and, an issue that is very dear to the heart and mind of the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), the establishment of a consortium of institutional investors in Optus Communications. AIDC's business activities have expanded to fee based merchant banking activities. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, AIDC experienced some substantial losses. In 1988, the AIDC went through a colourful period, including a recognised capital shortage by the Commonwealth government which led to the creation of AIDC Ltd and the Australian Stock Exchange listing of 19 per cent of AIDC Ltd in 1989. Of course the Commonwealth retained 81 per cent of the listed entity. For some years, and particularly during the Labor years obviously, the government talked of selling off the remaining interest in AIDC Ltd. As a result, there was great uncertainty regarding the future of the company. It is fair to say that this does have a damaging impact on the morale of staff and management and also of the board and that that may have contributed to some of the less than profitable years towards the end of the 1980s and the early 1990s. I am prepared to recognise that, particularly when in the 1992-93 budget the Labor government announced its intention to sell down, to 51 per cent, the government's share in AIDC Ltd. It was in August 1992 that the government recognised that this was going to prove very difficult and withdrew the sale. In 1993-94, we saw the Labor government do a backflip yet again on another issue when it said that it was going to pursue the sale. But then in April 1994 the Labor Party said that it may change its mind in relation to the sale process. In 1995, the former Labor government announced that they were going to go into the market and buy back from private investors the remaining 19 per cent of AIDC Ltd, the minority shareholding. They suggested that this was going to take place so they could properly prepare AIDC Ltd for a full sale at a later date. The takeover offer closed in January 1996 and AIDC was deIisted one month before the election last year. The federal government wants to sell AIDC because it is a good idea. It experienced losses in the late 1980s and early 1990s. It had a profit turnaround in 1993 and significant before tax profits in each of the years since. In 1995-96, AIDC Ltd had a record $50.3 million profit, which I will talk about a little later. It is, however, not in the public interest to retain public ownership of a merchant banking operation. There are, of course, many other investment banking operations in the Australian financial marketplace, but the government should not be involved in an operating business on a commercial basis in a competitive environment, especially where that competitive environment is related to the issuance of capital and the use of capital for profit purposes. This is entirely consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit. Further, it is fair to say that Australia enjoys very sophisticated financial markets and there is no public benefit for the Commonwealth in continuing to have an extensive involvement in the financial marketplace. For example, AIDC can enter into swaps agreements, foreign exchange agreements, forward rate agreements, option agreements, futures agreements and hedge agreements, all of which start to become complicated financial instruments once you start getting involved in derivatives of each of those and exotic agreements. These businesses have no place in the public sector other than to hedge the overall risk of the Commonwealth. The government is pursuing the competitive neutrality principle. There is an existing funding advantage for the Commonwealth, and the AIDC has enjoyed access to the Commonwealth's AAA domestic guarantee, which means that it should be an even more profitable enterprise than it is at the moment. I understand that the AIDC does not pay any guarantee fees to the Commonwealth for the benefit of enjoying the AAA status domestically and AA status on S&P rating in international markets. The termination of access to the government guarantee facility Will place the AIDC business where it belongs-on exactly the same footing as the rest of the financial services industry. There is an issue that has been brought to my attention over the last few weeks as I have been researching the sale process for AIDC Ltd. It is a matter of grave concern not just to this parliament but to all Australians, who in fact have a stake in the future of AIDC Ltd. It comes down to the fact that the AIDC management has taken a regressive approach to the sale process. AIDC management has served only its own interest during the sale process and there is a good reason for that, which I would like to elaborate on. As of the figures of 31 December 1996, a contingent liability for employee termination is in the accounts amounting to. around $32 million. This $32 million-most of which benefits around 50 of the total of 200 employees, which would be a rule of thumb application-would suggest that management has set for itself amongst the most lucrative employment contracts in the financial services industry in Australia. The company has net assets of around $246 million. So up to 15 per cent of the net asset figure would have to be allocated to the termination of employees and, particularly, senior management. That is an extraordinary figure. But it goes further. According to the 1996 annual report, the executive remuneration in AIDe Ltd has reached preposterous levels. As I referred to a little earlier, profits have improved. In the profit for AIDe Ltd was $47.3 million. In 1995, the profit was $25 million. In 1995, with a profit of $25 million, there were more than 10 executives in AIDe Ltd receiving over $700,000. More than 10 executives were receiving over $700,000 per annum in an organisation that has a total of 200 employees. That is an extraordinary figure. It is even more extraordinary, if you take the levels a little bit further, that 16 people received more than $250,000, and that was on a profit figure of $25 million. On a 1996 profit figure of $50.3 million, 18 executives received more than $250,000. Some would say-and it is fair, and I agree with it-that it is only appropriate that executives should receive benefits on the basis of the profit projections. But my concern is the fact that the 1995-96 so-called profit is primarily made up of a write back of asset values and loans. So, essentially, what the management has done, or is seen to have done, is revalue everything upwards to create a profit result in 1995-96 of $50.3 million, which seems to be almost a 100 per cent improvement on the previous year. I would not deny-nor would anyone, or very few, in this House-the right of senior management or talented people on the staff to have very generous salary packages based on the level of profit in the organisation. It is only appropriate in the financial services sector and particularly in the markets, where there are extraordinary pressures on individuals and there is extraordinary risk associated with decisions made less than every minute of every hour of every day. There are only too many examples where imprudent financial management has caused grave harm to organisations such as Barings, more recently Natwest in the United Kingdom, and a few other organisations. I think it was Nomura that was the unfortunate recipient of a billion dollar mistake. But when salary levels are pitched at such a high point and the underlying profit of an organisation does not indicate that they should be, then what they are doing is ripping off the shareholder. And that is exactly what the AIDe management have done. They have 1994, ripped off the shareholder by taking such excessive salaries and putting in place extraordinary termination agreements. In 1996, $25.9 million was the total salary package for AIDe Ltd-this puts it in perspective-and yet their termination agreements and the contingent liability in the accounts is $32 million, which would indicate that every employee in AIDe Ltd is guaranteed more than an entire year's salary for termination. You and I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the hard working personal assistant or hard working secretary or the young employee who is running to and from the market or doing the courier service or working in the photocopy room is not going to get a year's salary. So what does that mean about the senior executives' termination payments? And even now we need to ask the question: what is the motivation of the management and the board in impeding the smooth process to due diligence during the sale process? I will tell you what it is. It is an underlying arrogance. Professor Jeremy Davis was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 18 March as saying: The real core of AIDC's business li<!s in the relationship with our 80 to 100 clients. The exercise of this right to information could be damaging to the company. The report goes on to say: Professor Davis said AIDe was not looking for a veto but a limit to the due diligence process for buyers. Professor Davis is showing an extraordinary arrogance and a lack of understanding of the most basic sale principles for any financial institution. Professor Davis seems to have forgotten some of the lessons of the past. The State Bank of Victoria was never sold to the Commonwealth Bank-they never went through any due diligence process. The State Bank of South Australia was never sold to Advance Bank-they never went through any due diligence process. Bankwest was never sold to the Bank of Scotland-they never went through any due diligence process. The Commonwealth Bank was never sold to the markets-they never went through any due diUgence. process. And it goes on. State Bank was never sold to Colonial-there was no due diligence process. Metway. was never sold into the Bank of Queensland and the Queensland government-there was no due diligence process. And it goes on and on and on. And the Chairman of AIDC Ltd has the absolute hide to come into this parliament and tell the Senate committee that the due diligence process might unveil confidential information about customers. He either does not understand the most basic processes of due diligence or he is· guilty of the most heinous crime of obstructing the obvious will of the shareholders-the people of Australia. If Professor Davis is not going to comply with the demands of this parliament and the demands of the shareholder, then he should resign and take his entire board with him. Because what he is doing is saying to us that AIDC should be absolutely separate from the normal processes of sale, including the due diligence process, which will reveal the true value of the asset. As I have indicated, AIDC's profit result last year was not that good. They have chosen to revalue a few assets and inflated the profit figure but the underlying profit is disappointing-given that it has a AAA guarantee, which only three banks in the world have; only three banks in the entire world have an international AAA guarantee. And AIDC's domestic AAA and international AA give them significant benefits; yet on assets of $256 million last year their profit was $50.3 million with some revaluations tied in. On behalf of the people in my electorate and on behalf of the people in this House, I urge AIDC management to make a contribution to the sale process. The only message I am hearing-and I am standing on the sidelines-is that AIDC management are impeding at every point the smooth sale process. You know why? Because they have set up for themselves the most cosy executive remuneration contracts anywhere in the markets. They like their cosy little arrangement-their AAA guarantee, their wonderful termination payments, their wonderful remuneration payments. They do not even have to rely on substantial underlying profits to deliver them good remuneration. It is greedy and it is grubby! The sooner AIDC is sold into the market, the sooner it will be accustomed to real market pressures, the sooner the executives of AIDC will realise that the gravy train cannot continue, especially at the expense of the people of Australia. I call on the management of AIDC Ltd to lift their game. I warn them that not only am I am watching them, not only are the bidders carefully watching them, not only are the government and this House watching them but the market is watching them-and we are watching them very closely. If they are going to have that sort of attitude in this process, they are going to find it very hard to survive either the sale process or any process after that.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I will be supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). Let me say a couple things about the contribution from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey). It is all very well for the honourable member to draw these very serious concerns, which we agree with, about the operations of the AIDC and its management, but what does the AIDC Sale Bill 1997 provide to deal with your concerns? It does not provide very much at all. We have moved our amendment not just in relation to these concerns but in relation number of concerns that we have on the opposition side. We have a number of concerns about what is going on and about the way in which the government has dealt with this issue. Although we will not decline to give the bill a second reading, we will be moving amendments in the consideration in detail stage. We believe the second reading amendment focuses on some very important issues. The first issue has to do with philosophy, with the reasons why the AIDe is being sold. The honourable member for North Sydney presented many of the reasons.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: COMMITTEES
text: He has left the chamber, but he presented some good reasons. Basically, the AIDe has moved away from the purposes and philosophy for which it was created. But the danger here is that we will throw out the baby with the bathwater. The danger is-and this is certainly the view of the government according to the second reading speech-that the government does not see any role for an organisation such as the AIDe. We have a problem with an organisation. It is not performing the function for which it was originally created, so what do we say? 'Okay, that's the reason to get rid of the organisation.' On top of that, we then say, 'There is no reason for any organisation to perform that function.' We do not agree with that philosophically, politically and in terms of the economic development of this nation because the fundamental issue facing this nation at the moment is employment and unemployment. In order to effectively deal with that issue, we have to deal with the question of industry development. Industry policy is the crucial issue facing this House. It is a shame that it is so poorly addressed at the moment, with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism e Mr Moore) not having a clue, not having any ideas and not having any suggestions. On top of that, we have seen from this government a tax on programs designed to support and sustain industry. It is in this context that we have to understand this debate to a about the AIDe and the amendment moved by the opposition. We are saying in our amendment that we reaffirm a commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDe's creation. It might be reflective to talk about that for a moment. A document from the Parliamentary Library refers to the purposes for which the AIDe was formed. It states: The AIDe was established in 1970 ... the initiative of the Rt Hon. 1. MCEwen, then Minister for Trade and Industry, who saw the need to counter Australia's growing dependence on foreign capital to support its enterprises and industries. The AIDe is an investment bank which finances Australian industries and which also participates in enterprises and projects. MCEwen was not opposed to foreign investment per se and, in fact, he acknowledged the importance of the availability of such capital in Australia. The AIDe was created to assist Australian residents match the share of capital required to create or maintain enterprises so as to avoid too often becoming the minor partner in an enterprise which was the target of foreign investment or takeover. At that time, the Australian motor industry was nearly 90% foreign controlled. The industrial and heavy chemicals industry, and the pharmaceuticals industries were over 80% foreign controlled. Overseas ownership of the electrical and electronic industries was around 50%. The AIDe was created to fill a gap not then adequately covered by the banking and other financial lenders. The AIDe was there to assist in cases where the development would not otherwise take place, or would not be possible in circumstances where, unless local finance was available, ownership and control would go to foreign investors. A piece of history, Mr Deputy Speaker. We believe those general underlying principles of the AIDe are still relevant. But the government, in getting rid of the AIDe, is not putting in place any structure which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long-term patient funds for industry development. It does not address that. This is a critical issue for us as a nation, as a people. We have to develop more broadly and, as the shadow minister said, develop our industries throughout the regions of Australia, otherwise our future as a nation is going to be glum. We must do more in industry development but, without an organisation or a structure that takes up this task, it is going to be very difficult. So we condemn the government for not doing enough, not thinking enough and not putting into place sufficient policies to help develop a structure of this kind that can assist in the injection of capital. There is no doubt that the government does not see any such need because according to the second reading speech: Since its establishment as a company AIDC has been changing the direction of the business activity of the company. While still focusing on the opment or advancement of the infrastructure resource sectors of the economy, it is pursuing to a far greater extent fee-based merchant banking business. This government is firmly of the view that such activities have no place continuing public sector. That is the explanation that we get in the second reading speech when we try to underactually stand what the government is on about in terms of this concern with the financing industry. It is interesting to look at what philosophical basis of this concern second reading speech also says: The government's decision to sell the AIDC Limited is consistent with the recommendations the National Commission of Audit which conin sidered that government business activities whose objectives are to provide goods and services commercial basis should only be retained in public ownership if there is a clear public interest do so. With the emergence and development financial markets in Australia any public interest case to retain the AIDC in public ownership has disappeared. First of all, I suppose that means that the provision of capital is a good or service. That is interesting. Whoever wrote this perhaps should go back and look at their economics texts. It seems to them that the provision of capital is a good or service. They do not understand the fact that the banking sector does not sufficiently lend regional areas, in risk areas, in new areas in innovative areas. Yet in this country we have the problem that we have a large number of skilled people, a very highly skilled work Ireland. force, but we do not have enough industry for them to be employed in. Is it because we not have the general idea of what to do? Couldn't we in Australia produce whitegoods? Couldn't we in Australia produce electronic products? Couldn't we in Australia produce more telecommunications? Couldn't we in Australia have more processing of minerals? Couldn't we in Australia have more processing of food? Couldn't we in Australia have a whole range of other industries? Of course we could. Why don't we have a structure or a body which can actually help at least in the initial stages? This is a matter that is going to have to be taken up at some point or another. I can tell develyou that we on this side of the House are and determined to push this issue about industry development over and over again. If the government is not prepared to put into place in the a minister who is going to listen and who is going to be at least interested in the issues, if the government is not going to be prepared to start thinking in innovative ways about how we can proactively get our industries going, then we are going to be in a lot the of strife. But we are going to make this an is. The issue at the next election. The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), who is at the table, knows what of I am talking about because we were recently a parliamentary delegation that visited the Republic of Ireland. It was very instructive to on a see what can be done because in the Republic case to of Ireland they have converted from an of agriculturally based economy 20 years ago20 years ago only-into an economy based on high technology industries. And not only that; they have actually been able to develop those they think industries in the regions. How have they done that? Do you think they have done it by allowing everything to enter the free market without government intervention? On the contrary. As the honourable member for Ballarat knows, we were all stunned to see the number of concessions and in the number of active policies that were put and into place by a government owned organisation designed to achieve manufacturing, high technology industries regionally based in I am not saying that all of these industries do would be possible in Australia. By the way, we thought some of these were against the World Trade Organisation until we discovered how much you can actually do in the investment area. For example, some companies investing in manufacturing in Ireland have a reduced corporate tax rate to 10 per cent up to the year 2010. They are able to have a reduced tax for investment. There is a whole range of other initiatives-tax-free repatriation of profits in certain circumstances, tax exempt government securities, capital allowances and expenditure on scientific research-all sorts of measures put into place to ensure that you get the kind of investment that is required in industry. There is another serious aspect to this issue, and we have had quite a few serious aspects raised so far. We also had the serious questions raised by the honourable member for North Sydney. I look forward to seeing what the minister intends to put into place to deal with the issues he raised. There are also the matters raised by the honourable member for Hotham-the problem we face as a nation with so many regions spread out geographically, so many different places that need small and medium sized industries, industries where our people can work. Are you saying in the context of that that we do not need some kind of organisation? We certainly don't need the currently operating AIDC with all of its problems. But we need an organisation that is going to achieve those results. Unless we hear some answers from the government, we are going to be not only insisting on our amendment, but we are going to be keeping them on their toes over and over and saying, 'What are you going to do about a structure to provide capital for industry?' The other amendments that we are foreshadowing for after the second reading debate stage have to do with the Australian Submarine Corporation. What is the government going to do about the Australian Submarine Corporation? This is a very serious question. As the shadow minister for industry, the member for Hotham, has said, the opposition asked a few questions about this in the Senate committee hearings. It is instructive to read the text of key questions raised by Senator Robert Ray: Senator ROBERT RAY-Minister, you would realise that the Australian Submarine Corporation was designed to always have an Australian ownership. I think Kockums own about 48.5 per cent approximately and AIDC and the other by a small Australian shareholder. Will this open the possibilitythat is the sale of the AIDCof the Australian Submarine Corporation being owned in the majority overseas? Senator Kemp-That is not the government's intention, Senator Ray. Senator ROBERT RAY-It is not the government's intention but is there a possibility of that if AIDC is purchased in part by foreign owners and you do not actually transfer their holding of the Australian Submarine outside it? Senator Kemp-No. The advice I have is that that is not the government's intention and, clearly, if there was a potential problem in the area the submarine would be pulled out of the sale. Senator ROBERT RAY-Have you identified an area that you would transfer the asset to? An official answers: Mr Hutchinson-The propOSItIon is that the asset initially be held by the Australian Industry Development Corporation-the statutory authority-which would need to continue in operation for some time to manage the borrowings that are still in place and that run for some considerable period. So, in the first case, the corporation would hold the shares but it is possible to vest them elsewhere in the Commonwealth. Senator ROBERT RAY-Would you have any idea where else you could invest those shares? Mr Hutchinson-They could be vested in the Commonwealth directly so that the Department of Defence could hold them, or any other government agency so nominated by the administrative arrangements orders could hold them, or they could be vested in another Commonwealth entity, another Commonwealth GBE, if that was thought appropriate. Senator ROBERT RAY-There would be a great deal of awkwardness if it went to the Department of Defence because then it would be part owner and client, similar to the problems they have with Australian Defence Industries. You would have to put up all sorts of Chinese walls. Where else in the government, apart from Defence, do you think you could vest them to avoid those problems? Mr Hutchinson-If they were merely a financial asset they could be vested with the Department of Finance or the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism if that was appropriate. majority This is the key point: The ministers have given no consideration beyond the possibility that they could be held in corporation for some time. The ministers have given no consideration. The top official admits there is a problem and a very serious issue. The government says, 'No, we don't want to get rid of Australian ownership of the Australian Submarine Corporation. We are going to sell the AIDC, but we haven't given any consideration about what we are going to do about the issue.' What sort of a government is this? Here is a very key defence industry, the Australian Submarine Corporation. They say they don't want to put it out of Australian ownership and yet they have not done anything in terms of putting into place a plan to deal with it. Our amendments will deal with this issue directly. (Time expired)  speaking on the bill that allows the Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd to be sold off. We have had the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) on the government side intervene in this debate. I would just like to extend a general apology that there are no other government members speaking on the debate and, particularly, no National Party members. I find it extraordinary that no National Party member is sufficiently motivated by the current pressing issues of this bill or the history of the bill, because the AIDC was established when Black Jack MCEwen was Minister for Trade and Industry. I would have thought they would have wanted some pride of ownership on this and to make some comments about it. It is interesting that, when it was set up back in 1970, it was proposed as a mechanism for countering Australia's dependence on foreign capital to support its enterprises and its industry. That was a very worthwhile thing in 1970 and I make the point that it has remained as relevant in the 1980s and 1990s as it was in the 1970s. From our perspective on this side of the House, we are unapologetic about wanting to say that we support processes and mechanisms that allow Australian industry to grow and not to be owned by or dependent on foreign capital. It is ironic that we are supporting a measure to effectively privatise something owned by the Commonwealth. But, like a number of organisations, this institution, regrettably, has long departed from the original vision and aims that were had for it. That is a matter of regret, but it is the reality. So, in selling off AIDC, we are not selling something that is countering Australia's growing dependence on foreign capital to support enterprise and industry. This is not an organisation that is supporting technological breakthroughs any more. One of the things the AIDC can rightly claim some credit for is the fact that it funded the Nucleus Techtronics pacemaker. We need an Australian institution that is prepared to fund breakthroughs-the pacemaker, the cochlear ear implant or whatever the next generation of exciting products developed by our scientists and researchers may be. We do not have that institution. It is a great tragedy that, in a country so relatively small in size, we are and always have been capable of doing good research and providing breakthroughs but we have not been good at product development and getting things onto the market. In particular, all too often we have not been good at keeping things in Australian hands. People are getting more and more upset about this, as they understand that when these things go overseas or are bought out by foreigners, the jobs and the benefits go with them in the majority of cases. We have done all the hard yards to have that research breakthrough but another foreign company in another country will get all the benefits of it. So, when AIDC was funding projects like the pacemaker, it was a very important institution to us on this side of the House, but critically important to innovative Australian industry. They have had some other very important investments-and I want to talk about one in particular in some detail-but they have long since gone away from that role. If you read today's Financial Review, it talks about the AIDC entering vendor finance and wanting to get into deep partnership, but that will not be for the things that John MCEwen had in mind-that is, countering foreign investment. It will not be pumping a lot of money into these companies or doing something that a lot of other companies are doing already. So that is why I am speaking-with regret-in support of the bill, in principle. It is important to read the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). That says: That whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, and recognising that there were difficulties associated with the way the AIDe had moved from its original charter, this House: (1) reaffirms its commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDC's creation; (2) condemns the Government for not putting a structure in place which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long-term, patient funds for industry development;I say amen to thatand (3) calls on the Government to establish an effective means of supporting patient capital investment and to determine remedial strategies appropriate to today's environment. That amendment sums it all up. We hope that on the government side they will exhibit a concern for and interest in Australian industry, funding the development and the product stage of research and development-although they have cut back research and development-assisting innovative Australian companies to grow, to develop and to export. We cannot say, 'The banks will look after it: we have banks and they do those things.' They have an appalling record. They are the most impatient providers of capital. In the farming sector, it has been an absolute tragedy to see customers who have had relationships of 20 to 30 years--{)r even generations-with one bank, only to see that bank squeeze them out of their property and inheritance. They have done that to the farming sector and to industry as well. I regret both events. We cannot look to the banks-they are failing us-and so we need to look to other institutions. I sincerely hope that the government will consider these issues seriously, because, after all, they are concerned with Australian jobs. I particularly wanted to talk about the Australian Submarine Corporation. I suppose that in the heat of political debate lots may be said about a member of parliament. But when Kim Beazley was Minister for Defence he had an outstanding record of achievement, which I think no-one really disputes. I wanted to talk about what he did on the industry side. There were decisions made on things like transforming the docks down in Victoria and getting Transfield up and running and giving them the frigate project. In relation to the Submarine Corporation a huge decision was made that, 'No, we just won't sign up to an American submarine, a British submarine, a German submarine, or whatever. We want self-reliance in Australia and we are going to build the submarine in Australia.' In fact it was in South Australia. That was a huge decision, a gutsy decision, and a quite right decision. I do not want to quibble with that decision. But if you were to look at one element that you would wish to revisit, it would be the fact that there was not a majority Australian owner. The reason I say that is that the Submarine Corporation has never had the same ambitions for exports or exporting the submarine as I believe those who made the original decisions would have envisaged. What was the Australian institution that funded the 48.5 per cent shareholding? It was the AIDC. Is it not a tragedy that you could not get the Commonwealth Bank, the National Bank, the ANZ or the super funds to come into such an important project in the national interest that added skills and technology exponentiaIIy to our defence capability and self-reliance? We could not get anyone of those; we had to get the AIDe. So if there is now another purchase of important equipment-and the current Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan) says that it is vital, in the defence of Australia, in terms of self-reliance, that we have this capability in country-who is going to fund it? Regrettably, there is no institution. That is why I say to the government that we need to think in terms of developing an institution that could fulfil that role, if not others. As I say, it was a huge decision to build the submarine in Australia. I think the Submarine Corporation have done brilliantly. But my one area of criticism is the fact that they have failed to get into exports. I may even be as ungenerous to suggest that somehow Swedish options from Sweden seem to be more vigorously pushed in our region than were Australian Submarine Corporation options. What was the reason for that? We really never had tight enough control. The most amazing thing about this bill to sell off the AIDC is that Kockums still has pre-emptive rights to buyout the AIDC shareholding. So, in other words, if you want to privatise the AIDC, including its shareholding in the Submarine Corporation, you actually have to give Kockums the first right of refusal. I would have thought that that was a difficult process. I do not really think that government has thought through well how it is going to warehouse it. It may be a matter of, 'We can put it here-Finance; we can put it in industry and science-DIST; or we can warehouse it some other way.' I would have thought that in relation to Australian taxpayer funds the people of Australia would expect the government of the day to more seriously consider the implications of this move and to have a very clearly thought out approach to this problem. I am going to be followed in this debate by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), who has got some important contributions to make to this debate-I might say almost scandalous. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are in the chair, so this is not directed at you, but it is disappointing to me that there is no National Party member making a contribution to this debate, given that Black Jack MCEwen was the minister who actually established the AIDC, for reasons that I think were commendable in 1970 and for purposes in the 1970s which are still valid today. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, when I go around my electorate-I do not know what it is like in yours-people are concerned about the amount of foreign ownership. They are worried ihat there are not enough Australian owned companies. They feel that we as parliamentarians are not doing enough to assist, to push up and develop and grow our Australian owned companies and get them bigger and get them employing more Australians in jobs. This was one of the roles that Black Jack MCEwen saw for the AIDe. But it has moved away from that original objective and vision, and that is why we on this side of the House are supporting its sale. So in particular I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham and I support the bill.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: COMMITTEES
text: There has been a role for the AIDe. As other speakers pointed out, it was originally established to meet real needs in this community, particularly the reluctance of investors to put their money into regional Australia. Many of us would think that there is still a need for the type of service that the the AIDC was originally established to provide. But, as other speakers have also pointed out, it has moved away from that role and its focus on fee based merchant banking can just as readily be met by private sector banks. Therefore, the case for it remaining in the public sector diminishes accordingly. I also want to say that I think AIDC has lost its way in the last two or three years because of the focus of its own management on looking after themselves rather than looking after the purposes for which AIDC was established. Back in October 1995 there was considerable public comment and public concern expressed at the salary increases awarded by senior executives of AIDC to themselves of more than 200 per cent in a single year. The Managing Director of AIDC at the time, Mr Gerry van der Merwe, according to the Sunday Age, was paid a salary of $1.8 million, making him the second highest paid executive in the country. As I understand it, his salary was in fact $1.8 million, but he received $400,000 in options as well, which took him over the $2 million mark and made him the highest paid executive in the country. The Sunday Age compared him with BHP's chief executive who received $1.9 million. But, on the other hand, BHP had a staff of 49,000 and a profit in excess of $1 billion, whereas AIDC had a staff of only 200 and a profit of $28 million. Mr van der Merwe's salary had been boosted from $320,000 to $1.8 million in a period when the bank's profits fell from $46 million to $28 million. It is little wonder that Senator Peter Cook said at the time that he was astonished at the level of wage increases awarded to him. It was not just the managing director who was being paid these extraordinary salaries. By the end of 1995, the 10 highest paid executives at AIDC were earning between $700,000 and $1.8 million each. Their pay packets corresponded to 36 per cent of AIDC's after tax profits-a truly extraordinary amount when the company was only earning those small profits and only earning those small profits when it was the beneficiary of a government guarantee. This was at a time when the senior executives had sought and gained what were referred to as golden handcuff payments. They said they had to be paid these additional amounts of money because there was uncertainty surrounding the merchant bank's future. But it seems to me, looking at the AIDC figures, that the huge percentage which was ripped off for those top salaries meant that the company was in a considerably worse position than if they had left the company. In any event, Mr van der Merwe received two retention payments-the second of which was $400,000-and he resigned one week after receiving that second retention payment. AIDC's profits were $28 million in 1994, $43 million in 1993 and $46 million in 1992 against a background where they had a preferential interest rate as a AAA rated beneficiary of the federal guarantee. So all they had to do was take money and lend it on to the National Bank, making use of the guarantee in order to make a return. The management in place at that time failed to generate new income streams and lived off the diminishing returns of the old AIDC income and that income was based on a continuously falling asset base. In my view, this amounted to a straight rip-off of the taxpayer and amounted to conduct like kids in a candy shop. It is against that background-of executives having negotiated uncommercial retention packages for themselves and highly profitable golden handshakes-that I think we have to ask a number of questions now surrounding the sale to ensure that the public interest will be protected. I for one am interested in knowing what assets AIDC has sold since the 1996 election and for what value; how do those sales prices compare with an independent assessment of the market value of those assets which have been sold; have there been independent assessments of market value; and was there a commercial reason for the asset to be sold when it was? It is certainly my understanding that bonuses being paid to AIDC executives related to asset sales. So AIDC had a motivation to sell assets, particularly prior to 30 June, irrespective of whether it was getting full value for money. I think we need to understand whether there have been independent assessments of those asset sales. We also need to understand what kinds of golden handshakes or contracts for senior management are now in place. Would it be the case that we may get a lower price for the sale of AIDC due to lucrative golden handshakes and contracts for senior management in the event that the new owner of AIDC decides to get rid of the senior managers? Based on the retention payments that occurred in the past, it is quite possible that we would have arrangements in place whereby management gets golden handshakes of such a size that they would tend to diminish the price for AIDC. In my view these are important questions, and I would like to hear responses from the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) before this debate is concluded. AIDC currently employs 200 people. While, as I have indicated, Labor does not want to see generous golden handshakes go to AIDC senior management, we are concerned that ordinary workers in the organisation are not disadvantaged by the sale. It is my understanding that concerns were expressed about this during the Senate committee hearings on Monday. I am pleased, as other opposition members would be, that assurances have now been given that the existing terms and conditions of employment for these workers will be maintained. AIDC is one of two Australian controlled independent investment houses. It is likely that through this sale it will be purchased by overseas interests. There are no sions in the bill to deal with foreign ownership. Against this background, Labor notes the assurances of Senator Kemp that, if the buyer is overseas owned, AIDe's 48.5 per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation could be excluded from the sale. We believe that better assurances should be given, and the amendment we will move to this bill goes to this point. We will move that the ASC be removed from AIDC Ltd and be located within the AIDC corporation, which is to stay in place to manage the borrowings and loan portfolio and to manage such national interest assets as the Commonwealth's Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding. That would ensure that the Australian Submarine Corporation does not become foreign controlled. I want to express some concern about the sale of the AIDe. While the points for the sale are understood by the opposition and we are not opposing the sale, if there is to replace the AIDC, that does form part of a pattern of conduct by this government which is detrimental to regional Australia. We have seen $150 million cut from regional infrastructure projects. That was justified by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, on the grounds that there was no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. In other words, he was saying, 'We are washing our hands of involvement in regional development.', We have also seen a budget which impacted massively on regional Australia. So people who relied on regional roads and infrastructure, people who relied on higher education-, because the cuts fell disproportionately on regional campuses-and people who relied on assistance to the unemployed have all been massively disadvantaged. ABC funding was cut. There were massive attacks on regional welfare, with the closure of regional CES, tax and Medicare offices. Against that background, it is a matter of concern that the government looks to have some appropriate replacement for AIDC to continue investment special provi- in regional Australia. I do want to repeat the concerns I expressed earlier in my speech, and I want to raise those questions about the kinds of golden handshakes which are involved for AIDC management and the kinds of asset sales that have been engaged in in recent times. What we have had is a situation where AIDC management knew it was the government's intention to sell AIDC-so they knew they were going-and, therefore, there was no incentive for them to behave in a way which was in the best interests of AIDC or the best interests of the taxpayer. It really was a situation which encouraged kids in the candy store behaviour. I am anxious to hear from the government the full details of arrangements concerning golden handshakes and asset sales which have been conducted during the past 12 months.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The AIDC Sale Bill is a bill to privatise a government entity. I think I should at least be no effort consistent and express my concernMr Ronaldson-Pre-election or postelection?

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: COMMITTEES
text: No. The honourable member for Ballarat could find plenty of examples of consistency on this matter of privatisation even before the election. If he is really all that interested in it, I refer him to my speech on the sale of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in October 1993. I would like briefly to address that aspect. I am quite happy to stand here in support of the second reading amendment moved by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and indicate that we understand the reasons behind the government's decision to proceed with the sale, but we do not understand the total reasons as they were explained in the second reading speech. The reliance in the second reading speech on the support this sale has from the National Commission of Audit is one aspect that would cause me great concern. The nature of that comment by the National Commission of Audit is to indicate that perhaps a government has no business in the types of activities that the AIDC involves itself in. I think there can be, in various ways, a case put for government involvement in a whole range of activities and that we should not shy away from that. They should be considered just as much as any of the alternatives that government has before it. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you would understand the historical links and involvement of government activity in public enterprises, such as railways and other public utilities. As was said earlier in this debate, government ownership and involvement in activities like that has been very important, especially to the regions of Australia. When we have gone through the sales we have had over the past few years, one of the arguments that has always been put is that historical basis for government ownership of such organisations as the Commonwealth Bank or Qantas is no longer applicablethings have changed, and the nature of those organisations has changed. To a certain extent in the case of the AIDC, that is the basis for the reasoning on the move towards the total sale. In the case of AIDC, it has acknowledged that it has moved away from its original charter. We should also look at that. In we should be looking at the reasons why AIDC was created some 20 to 30 years ago and whether those reasons still should look at vehicles like the AIDC as being important alternatives for involvement of government in ensuring that there is adequate fund provision for a whole host of projects, most particularly, as the shadow minister has said, infrastructure development. An article in this morning's Melbourne Age discusses the superannuation tax-the soup called superannuation surcharge-and its unintended effect on the ability for funds managers to invest in major infrastructure regard. projects. It indicates that the funds managers have some concern that their ability to provide funding will even further dry up, and can take that in the context of the likelihood of the infrastructure bonds being scrapped. What needs to be asked is: how are we going to find these alternative sources of funding ensure that major projects, the likes of which the AIDC has been involved in, and which have been outlined in this debate, will continue? As I have said, I do not believe that the process of privatisation itself will make an organisation any more efficient. I do not believe that it is somehow inherent in the nature of the private sector to always do things more efficiently and effectively. I believe that there is always a role for government ownership as a form of government intervention in the economy, whether it be to achieve important social objectives that the private sector will not deliver on or because of the benefit in terms of the revenue that flows to government. Telstra is an example that fulfils both of these categories. I note in the this context that the AIDC has provided more than $130 million in dividend payments since 1983. Having said that about my concerns of public ownership vis-a-vis private ownership, some of the criticisms that have been made about the AIDC in government ownership likewise indicate that, on occasions, we have to be vigilant that organisations in government ownership do the right thing as well. The issue that has been raised most notably 1997 by the honourable member for North Sydney the (Mr Hockey) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) is the matter of obtain. We executive salaries. I would have to say, having listened to the honourable member for North Sydney in his considered consideration of those matters, that the real danger is that this is symptomatic not just of behaviour within the AIDC as an organisation but of executive salaries across the board. This is an issue that I have taken on other occasions. I do not believe that we can finger one organisation for what appears to be exorbitant behaviour in that The whole matter of executive salaries is a we matter that government, on behalf of the people of Australia, should be looking into. It is something we should be doing all we can to put a cap on. If it is good enough for to ordinary workers to have to put in work value cases to justify pay increases and to justify their level of remuneration, there should likewise be mechanisms that ensure executive salaries have the same constraints. It is expected that government business enterprises perform to the same standards that are required in the private sector. As I have just suggested, it does not mean that they have to perform to the same low standards on some important matters. The selling of an enterprise in itself will not make the enterprise any more effective in doing what it does. There is no reason why these objectives are not able to be achieved in full public ownership. The measures required to bring a government business enterprise to what is considered to be a more competitive standard can be just as easily implemented with the organisation remaining in full public ownership. A public enterprise is a way for governments to promote certain social objectives and act as models for private sector businesses in areas such as progressive industrial relations or providing goods or services to disadvantaged customers. Privatisation always fails to take into account the fact that government business enterprises are often created to fill a need that was not being met by the private sector. This was the case with the former government's business enterprises like the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, which was designed to protect Australia's national interests by ensuring that Australia did not have to rely on other countries for sera and vaccines. This was the case when the Commonwealth moved into the area of telecommunications to ensure that all Australians had equal access to communications. I note that this is something which can no longer be guaranteed now that Te1stra is to be partially privatised. In the context of a debate about public ownership, I also have urged governments of, now, both persuasions to look at areas that they should pick up on. At the time when they are divesting themselves of ownership in certain areas, there is likewise a need to consider the important areas in the 1990s, going into the next century, where government can have a role. Recently in a discussion about the cable roll-outs of both Optus and Telstra, I, in not just a flippant way, said that perhaps what we needed to do was nationalise the cables. If the cables were in direct government control, with access to the cables then being on-sold to the telecommunication companies, we would have had greater control originally and could have greater control about the way in which they fulfil community expectations, the way in which it is an environmentally sensitive issue, the way in which they fulfil the necessary expectations about their capacity and the way in which they would be able to bring things into households. The banking sector did not adequately provide the necessary capital to finance industries. This was the rationale behind the establishment of the Australian Industry Development Corporation back in 1970. It was envisaged that, in a case where development would not proceed, or would only proceed with ownership and control going to foreign investors, the AIDC could step in. The AIDC has a 48.5 per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation. The rationale behind this investment was the same-there needed to be Australian investment in an undertaking of such national significance. The issue of possible foreign ownership of such a vital holding as a result of AIDC's privatisation is of concern. As a consequence of this legislation, the AIDC could end up being controlled by foreign investors. While the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) has given undertakings that the Australian Submarine Corporation holding could be removed from the sale should this prove to be the case, the opposition would like to see that stated more clearly in the legislation. Therefore, the opposition will move an amendment, in the consideration in detail stage of the debate, which would ensure that the Australian Submarine Corporation holding will be removed from the AIDC and that it will not end up in foreign hands. This is a clear example of my concern. Whilst the market forces apply in this-and market forces are all important-they do not necessarily act in the national interest. Market forces actually act in the interests of the market. Given that there has been a globalisation of our economy and an integration into the international economy, we cannot be sure that, without proper instruments of intervention by government, market forces will prevail in the national interest. When considering the privatisation of the AIDC, the original objectives of the organisation should be re-examined. The AIDC was established in 1970, as I said, to promote the development of Australian industry and Australian participation in it. There is agreement from both sides of this place that the AIDC has shifted away significantly from the original function that it performed. While the AIDC has progressively moved away from this over time to a more fee based merchant banking institution, the government needs to look at alternative methods of assistance. The movement away from its original role has been further exemplified in an article in today's Financial Review headed 'AIDC enters into vendor finance', which the member for Hotham has referred to. In privati sing the Australian opment Corporation, the government should not think this action absolves them of responsibility for assisting industry to access capital. This is because the problems facing many Australian companies in gaining access to capital still remain, and, as I have suggested, perhaps are getting much worse. The result of this is that many projects get under way only because of foreign investment, if at all. Given the government's current attempts to remove itself from every aspect of industry policy, I do not hold out much hope of the government recognising this. Because the AIDC has moved away from its original objectives, it is now appropriate for the government to examine the creation of an organisation or an instrument that is more in keeping with the AIDC's original function or look at other measures designed to assist business in gaining access to capital. There is certainly a need for an organisation which has as its function the provision of finance for promoting and developing Australian industry. When one looks at some of the infrastructure projects that the AIDC has been involved in, such as the two water treatment plants in New South Wales, one sees that in many cases they are projects of national significance. The government must ensure that a mechanism exists which allows such vitally important projects to be funded, and invested in, when they otherwise might not. One of the functions that the AIDC has under section 8A allowed the minister to provide the funds for investment in special projects deemed to be in the national interest. The sale of the AIDC will lose a vehicle that the minister had at hand to ensure that that could be so. It definitely would be in the national interest to have this function transferred to another body or taken up directly by the government itself. As I said at the outset, I support the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Hotham on the basis that it reaffirms the commitment of this House to the principles underpinning AIDC's creation and, further, condemns the government for not putting in place a structure which will address the failure of the capital markets to provide the sort of funding that the AIDC historically Industry Devel- had provided. It is now time that the government, through whichever minister wishes to take the reinsperhaps members in this debate are fast losing faith in the industry minister to provide adequate leadership--ensures that Australian industries continue to be able to not only maintain their market shares internationally but also grow, and ensures that we will not see further losses of Australian jobs offshore in important industrial sectors like pharmaceuticals and TCF. For instance, I was told, from a briefing given to the opposition yesterday, that if the TCF tariffs are to go to zero levels early in the next century it would lead to a loss of 700 jobs in one of the municipalities in my electorate. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in my electorate we cannot afford to lose one job. There are thousands of people who are ready, willing and able to take up worthwhile employment. The government has to recognise that there are many regions, such as the electorate that I represent, that need the assistance and intervention from government to ensure that Australian industry prospers.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I have listened to the debate today and appreciate that there is a universal view that the subject of the AIDC Sale Bill, AIDC Ltd, is pursuing business activities which make it no longer appropriate to be maintained by government ownership. Whatever the benefit of this particular organisation when it was established-a number of speakers in the course of this debate have referred to various projects that were of benefit to the community generally in an infrastructure sense-it has long past being useful. It has lost its way somewhat simply because of the fact that there has been a deregulation of banking and there are other facilities available for the type of infrastructure that AIDC once supported. The judgment that this business is not appropriate for government is one that has been held by both sides of the House-by the current government and by is predecessorsfor a number of years. Sale measures had been initiated previously, but had not met with much success. The lessons from those previous actions have been learned and led to the legislation currently before the House which will enable this government to bring the sale of AIDC Ltd and its associated business activities to a successful conclusion. The government will be opposing the opposition's amendments relating to the Australian Submarine Corporation holding. I made it clear during the second reading speech that the ASC holding would be quarantined from the sale. Therefore, this amendment is unnecessary. This legislation was necessary because the existing legislative framework governing the operations of the Australian Industry Development Corporation did not provide the flexibility that is necessary to conclude a sale on satisfactory terms and conditions. In addition, despite the successful takeover proposal conducted by the corporation for the shares it did not own in AIDC Ltd, minority shareholdings in the company continued to exist for technical reasons. With the passage of this bill, it will be possible to deal with those holdings in an expeditious manner without in any way compromising the fair and equitable treatment of those shareholders. The bill clearly makes provision to protect the interests of those parties, consistent with the obligations set out in the constitution for the compulsory acquisition of property. Another fundamental issue dealt with by the bill is that it provides the appropriate legal environment for the substantial financial interests of the Commonwealth to be managed both during and after the sale process. A significant characteristic of the business activities of AIDC Ltd has been the added protection afforded its borrowings through the use of the Commonwealth guarantee. With the sale of the company, or its assets, the Commonwealth will continue to stand behind the guarantees that it has already provided, but in so doing it is necessary to ensure that the Australian Industry Development Corporation is provided with the appropriate legislative base to continue that task. The bill provides that base. Concern has been expressed by the board of AIDC Ltd in relation to the power provided by this bill for the minister to require the provision of information to assist in the sale process. The concern was expressed on the basis that that may impact on the company's client relationship. I can assure the House that this power will not be used lightly by the government. The Commonwealth will be mindful of the need to protect commercially sensitive material and will ensure that commercial interests are not prejudiced during the sale process. The bill makes provision for the protection of information obtained under this arrangement. However, it is also important to ensure that the Commonwealth's actions, as the beneficial owner of AIDC Ltd, are not unnecessarily constrained and ensure that an effective power of veto is not provided to third party interests. In progressing this asset sale, in common with other recent asset sales, it is important for the Commonwealth to protect its financial interest and ensure that it receives full value from the sale. For this reason, the bill makes the necessary provisions to protect the sale from the imposition of stamp duty and cancels any residual franking credits that may exist in the company at the time of the sale. The approach to these provisions is consistent with provisions in other sale legislation which this House has previously passed. Similarly-and I note a number of speakers on the other side commented on this--employee interests have been protected by the provisions relating to long service leave and occupational health and safety. In other words, all the benefits that have currently accrued to the employees of AIDC Ltd will be protected through this legislation and will be passed on in appropriate circumstances to those employees. With a maturing financial and merchant banking industry in Australia, it is important that the government progress this sale and thereby remove itself from this area of business activity. I commend the bill to the House. Question put: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's amendment) stand part of the question. The House divided. [11.53 a.m.] (Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER - Mr J.N. Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Mr Andrew)I remind members while I have their attention, particularly the members for Fisher, Kennedy, Stirling, Herbert and ChifIey, that the dress code appears not to have been adhered to in this division. There will be subsequent divisions on this bill and this chair would expect the dress code to be adhered to in those divisions. Honourable members-Hear, hear! Original question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Consideration in Detail Schedule 1, items 1 to 38-by leave-taken together and agreed to. Schedule 1, item 39.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments Nos 1 to 3: (1) Schedule I, page 15 (after line 10), after the heading of Division 3, insert: 33HA Minister for Finance to direct AIDe Ltd to transfer asset (1) The Minister for Finance shall, by written notice given to AIDC Ltd, direct that body to transfer all of its holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation to the Corporation. (2) The direction may impose on AIDC Ltd requirements that are ancillary or to the transfer, including (but not limited to) any of the following requirements: (a) a requirement that the transfer must be completed no later than 30 June 1997; (b) a requirement that the transfer must be undertaken in a specified manner; (3) AIDC Ltd must comply with the direction. (4) To avoid doubt, nothing in this Act or in any other Act authorises the Minister to transfer from the Corporation its holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation. (2) Schedule I, page 15 (line 13), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance". (3) Schedule I, page 16 (line 4), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance". We foreshadowed these amendments in the second reading debate because of our specific concern about what happens to the Australian Submarine Corporation shares. We believe that the Submarine Corporation and the arrangements that the Labor government developed in relation to it-its strategic partnership with Kockums, its involvement and establishment in Adelaide and the huge growth in industry development that occurred consequent upon that-are a shining example of what can sensibly be done if the leverage of government policy together with the financing that backed it from the AIDC can be brought together. We believe there is still some potential future to build off the success of the Submarine Corporation. It is for that reason that we would obviously be reluctant to see the Submarine Corporation sold off as part of the arrangement that will sell off AIDC, the share package that the AIDC holds in the Submarine Corporation. That being said, we note that it is the intention of the government, in abolishing AIDC Ltd by the legislation, to still keep the corporation within AIDC ostensibly to manage the loans. We are saying that, in addition to the management of the loans, the corporation should hold the Submarine Corporation shares. We think it is important not just for the strategic national interest that Australia incident control its own defence capability but that there be future opportunities for the development of a defence based industry in this country, and the ability to develop that clearly is going to be significantly limited if the government still is not in the game. Our approach is to keep the government in the game, not by taking the shares back but by recognising where they are held and by parking the management of those within the AIDe. It also would require there to be some bipartisan discussion as to what the government's future intentions may be in relation to the shareholding of Submarine Corporation. We believe we can inject some sensible input and hope that the government might be prepared to embrace us in that approach in trying to develop a strengthened industry off our defence capability, off our shipbuilding industry, off our heavy engineering capacity, but really moving more into the strategic development, the high-tech industries, associated with defence and sense tracking, and recognising the significance that that has, quite frankly, for the manufacturing industry. When you think of the manufacturing industry generally, it is the software packages and the engineering dimensions that are important. It is not just a question of the pLysical infrastructure; it is the processes by which that technology is run. It is the systems running; it is the information technology. If Australia is to continue its growth in manufacturing exports, and that growth has already been significant, we need to use strategic inputs and strategic placements and the government needs to be in there as a partner with industry in securing a future direction for this nation. We therefore think that this amendment ought to be supported by the government. It is still saying that it can look to deal with it as it would like but that there would be a requirement to have wider discussions as to what its intentions might be. We accept the assurance of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) that it is not intended to sell the Submarine Corporation into foreign interests, but we are seeking to secure the base in this country for the Submarine Corporation and that which flows from it.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: PAIRS
text: ---I also support these amendments to the AIDC Sale Bill. In my speech in the second reading debate I made a couple of comments about what had happened in terms of answers to questions in the Senate. In the answers I quoted from the Senate committee hearing, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), who was representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), made it perfectly clear after questions from Senator Ray that it was not the intention of the government to sell the Australian Submarine Corporation to foreign interests. But, after a series of questions, it came out that the government and the minister have not put forward any proposal as to how that is to be avoided when the AIDC is sold. We do not know what is going to happen. I hope the minister is going to tell us. What is actually going to happen to the Australian Submarine Corporation? How is the minister going to ensure that that does not happen in the general context of the sale of AIDC Ltd? Interestingly, when asked what the options are, the top official said the government had made no determination. Even though the government have said on the one hand that they want to retain the 100 per cent-and they have brought the bill forward, they are saying they are selling the AIDC Ltd-they have not made a determination on this key aspect of the future of the Australian Submarine Corporation. Given that situation, when asked, the official said, 'Well, one option is to actually do what this amendment proposes', which is to hold the shares in the AIDe. So that is one option, and this is an option which we are urging in terms of these amendments. So we would urge the government to accept this amendment. They have been properly structured and their implications have been looked at. We urge the government to accept these amendments, to accept this approach, and let us give at least some security to the Australian Submarine Corporatioll in terms of its Australian ownership. As the shadow minister said, as we move into further discussions on the future of Defence Industries, we can then have that body in that place at least for the time being until we determine some further important issues in relation to Defence Industries. I also think that we should have some kind of broad discussion in this parliament on the future of Defence Industries and what is to happen after the AIDC is sold. We have supported the AIDC Ltd sale, but we are saying to the minister, 'Look after the Australian Submarine Corporation. Let us clearly state what the intention of the government is, and let us adopt these amendments.'

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: PAIRS
text: The Australian Submarine Corporation is particularly important to the Australian government and to the Australian people-both because of its importance to Australian defence and because of its importance to Australian industry. The government's significant holding in the Submarine Corporation via the AIDC is not something that should be allowed to go through with the passage of this bill without clear views being expressed by the parliament on that important matter. It is appropriate that the parliament place some restrictions upon the sale of the AIDC to ensure that the Submarine Corporation remains for the time being with a government stakeholding in it. The relevant amendment moved by the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), clearly provides a mechanism through which that can occur to ensure that the Submarine Corporation's government shareholding is kept in the AIDC. That opens up a number of opportunities further down the track as part of the development of Australian defence industry policy, and indeed, more broadly, industry policy for other sectors, because defence industry so often is at the cutting edge of technology developments and where defence industry goes so too does the broader industry sector. Can I quickly say a couple of words about the Submarine Corporation and its importance to defence. The Submarine Corporation has now managed to construct three submarines as part of an order of six, which are without doubt amongst the best in the world and regarded by many as being the most significant non-nuclear submarines anywhere in the world. That is a capability that is important to Australia's defence. It is a capability that opposition take very seriously. Indeed, it is a capability that was established during the period in which Labor was in office, when Kim Beazley and later Robert Ray as ministers for defence strongly supported the acquisition of those submarines and supported the Australian government's involvement in that project to ensure that it came to fruition and to ensure that there was a substantial Ian participation in the management of the organisation. I am not sure that that is a commitment that is shared by both sides of the parliament, and I would invite the minister at the table, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), to take the opportunity in this debate to make that clear. It is worth noting that in terms of the commitment on this side of the parliament to the Submarine Corporation and the defence importance of that program, we have made it plain that were we in government we would commit to the additional two submarines, 7 and 8. I invite the Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan), who is in the chamber, to address that issue to see whether or not the government is serious about maintaining a significant defence capability in submarine development, maintenance and construction. It is important to the Labor Party. It was important to us in government and it remains important to us in opposition. In relation to the defence industry implications of the Submarine Corporation, it is not just that the Submarine Corporation has produced an absolute world leader in submarine warfare; it is the long line of domestic companies who supply to the Submarine Corporation who have also benefited. The downstream suppliers to the Submarine Corporation number in their thousands. Many of those are local firms who have been pulled along by the submarine program into hightech areas and, as a result of that, are now competing successfully in world markets for the various components provision. That is an important consideration in the long-term sustainability, not just of the Collins class submarine but in terms of the development of new classes of warships and other platforms. That is a capability we the should not see let go. It is important that in dealing with the sale of the AIDC the parliament places these strictures on the sale. The parliament should ensure through this particular amendment that the shareholding in the Submarine Corporation remains for the time being with the government, that it is parked in the AIDC. It is a very sensible and worthwhile amendment, and I do hope the governAustral- ment accepts it.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: PAIRS
text: I have noted the contributions that have been made in respect of these amendments by the members opposite.
