In that we have indicated there is no intention to dispose of that shareholding with the sale of AIDC Ltd, the government reserves its flexibility and the legislation provides for where it puts that shareholding in the foreseeable future. By this amendment it is suggested that it should be put in the corporation. The Labor Party is saying that the government must place this shareholding in AIDC Ltd. Well, the government could place that shareholding in the defence portfolio, and I wonder what the objections to that might be from the members opposite. It could place it in the industry portfolio because, from the contributions of the members opposite, the debate centres around the industry that is associated with the Australian Submarine Corporation. It could place the ASC in Australian company-a company approved by the Department of Defence and approved by Kockums who has a shareholding in the matter Australian Submarine Corporation as well. it could place the ASC in that most approprihere, ate department for protecting the assets government-the Department of Finance. It could be placed in any of those portfolios to do. the point where the shareholding continues in government ownership. But what we really have to look at here is not restricting it. We have to look at the that this Submarine Corporation is involved in the construction of submarines. In July last year, the first Collins class submarine launched. There are five more that are being constructed under contract over the next several years, and that is not going to change. That is going to be there for the defence capability of Australia. As each one comes off, gets into the water and becomes operdone ational, that enhances the defence capability er. of Australia. That is not at risk in terms of the shareholding by AIDC Ltd in the Australian Submarine Corporation. I have indicated it is not intended to sell that shareholding. I have indicated that the government-clearly with the support of the Department of Defence and the Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan)-will make sure that what happens to that shareholding is in the best interests of Australia and in the best interests of the defence forces. Speaker: Mr MOSSFIELD
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I rise in this grievance debate to express my concerns about the needs of older people in our community with disabilities and their older carers. My remarks will be based on a study carried out on behalf of the Mullauna Retirement Village at Blacktown run by the Uniting Church. I propose to quote at length from this report as the findings must surely be mirrored across Australia. Mullauna is seeking to extend its services to older people with disabilities and older people caring for people with disabilities both in the provision of accommodation and in home support. The Mullauna group believe they should be extending their services based on community needs in the following areas: residential and in-home; as part of a continuum of care; with consideration for affordability; with adequately skilled respite carers; with consideration for the needs of older non-English speaking people and Aboriginal people; in more innovative forms, for example, accommodation for both carers and the person receiving care; and to develop its expertise to cater for older people with sengrievance sory disabilities and dementia. The results of the report I am using today would surely apply equally to many other in parts of Australia. The Blacktown local intengovernment area could be described as a We financially constrained area based on the of the relatively high proportion of to people living in public housing. This group represents 14.9 per cent of the Blacktown not population, which is well above the state average of 5.6 per cent. There is also a relatively high proportion of older people on right very low income support. This low income support would be an impeding factor in as obtaining assistance from community and the privately based services for domestic and personal care support. The report says: Blacktown has a relatively high proportion of residents (33.6%), 65 years and over, who were born in a non-English speaking country (NESC). Blacktown is the 4th highest LOA in the state regarding residents, 65 years and over from NES countries. The Western Sydney Area Health Service, in a study of older people in western Sydney from NES countries, stated that it is estimated that in five years time, 25% of all older people in Australia will be from a NESC. In Blacktown there are seven retirement villages comprising self-care and hostel units. There are 10 nursing homes. In total there are 17 establishments which have either self-care, hostel or nursing home places or a combination of these forms of accommodation. The Department of Community Services manages four group homes for people with intellectual disabilities and funds a further 13 homes managed by community or church organisations. This group home accommodation mainly caters for a younger population. In total there are fewer than 10 people over 60 in these homes. A coordinator of a number of these group homes stated that these older residents often suffer from early forms of dementia. As a result they are not able to manage in the group homes because of staffing numbers. The report went on to say: The extent of community outreach services by retirement villages in Blacktown was not investigated, except to note that Mullauna manages 30 community aged care packages. It is known that some of the community and church managed group homes provide support to assist people with intellectual ability living alone or with carers in the Blacktown area. Accommodation is sought in mainstream hostels and nursing homes. Service providers say that it is very difficult to find such hostels or nursing home placements. They are often forced to seek placements out of Blacktown. There is a strong demand for respite accommodation. The resultant waiting list for planned respite means that there is little opportunity for emergency residential care. Also, people with disabilities often have complex care needs that cannot be met in available respite facilities, thereby increasing the concerns of carers of these people. This very important report I am quoting from went on to say: While nursing homes and hostels may be inappropriate forms of accommodation for people under 65 years with disabilities, they have· often been the only forms of respite for carers of people with disabilities. Carers support groups report that in recent times even these 'inappropriate' forms of respite are becoming less available, even though there have not been any changes to legislation or departmental policy in this regard. This report indicates that there is still a significant number of older people with disabilities or handicaps in Blacktown who are managing to assist each other or are being assisted by some family member without any outside help. The older Aboriginal people's needs in this area have never been addressed; they are unique because the elders are much revered. Supply the hostel with the appropriate skilled staff and the families will do the rest. They also have a significantly shorter life span than other groups. Non-English speaking older persons have special needs with dementia in any form that sets in. The first, of course, is language. Therefore the need for hostel and nursing home care in their mother tongue is absolutely essential. Stroke victims are also there in very high proportions, another horror for the victim and the carers. Stroke debilitates different sections of the brain. Persons who lose the power of dis- speech can be locked into a world we dare not envisage. Then others lose use of limbs and cannot feed themselves or control their bodily functions. Carers are usually the partner until either the carer bums out ot ceases physically to be able to perform the needs of the victim. The conclusion in the report is that there is considerable scope to extend services to support older people with disabilities, especially older carers. The report says: The potential for expansion of residential services in Blacktown is virtually non-existent. It seems very unlikely that the Commonwealth government (which administers and funds hostel, nursing homes and community aged care package programs) will extend these forms of care in Blacktown. In the report, service providers pinpoint the greatest area of un met service needs for older people with disabilities and older carers as: respite care, both regular and emergency, both in residential care and at home; community transport, more extensive and more appropriate; assistance to overcome housebound isolation for both those with disabilities and carers. This isolation was also linked to associated needs of more information on available services and the provision of training for carers; and more networking of services to promote complementarity and flexibility of service provision. Finally, the Mullauna report indicates that more than 50 per cent of the older population of Blacktown with its multicultural character has some disability. Service providers in Blacktown indicate that there are some urgent unmet needs for older people with disabilities and older carers in the area. By far the greatest need was for more respite services both in residential care and inhome respite. The demand for respite is constantly increasing, leading to long waiting lists and diminishing opportunities for emergency respite. Further needs include more flexible and more extensive community transport, the alleviation of housebound social isolation and the development of better networking of residential and community based services. I hope that this report on the needs of older people with disabilities and older carers will lead to improved services for those most deserving people, and I compliment the Mullauna village on their important work. I would be happy to table the report for the information of all honourable members. I will conclude by referring to a statement by Ellen Long, who is the secretary of the National Seniors Association at Blacktownthis being Seniors Week in New South Wales-and let her have the last say on this issue. I have asked Ellen Long to make some submission to me relating to this particular matter, and I will read her short comments: Group homes in Blacktown LGA-there are many. Most of these homes have intellectually impaired persons, some have one or several disabilities. Most of these houses have three to five residents, one only has ten. The problems applying to these are many and complex .,. Aging process in our intellectually impaired persons is an enormous . problem.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I rise in this grievance debate today to speak to the House about one of the most tragic and distressing problems facing our community; that is, the abuse and neglect of children. We are all aware of the extensive media coverage recently of the sexual abuse of children by paedophiles. This is obviously a serious problem in our society. However, today I want to speak about the abuse and neglect of children by their families, because the most common child abuse offenders-both sexual and nonsexual-are family members. Indeed, a national study by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare showed that natural parents were responsible in more than two-thirds of abuse and neglect cases. Yet the fact that abusive and neglectful behaviour towards children most often occurs at the hands of family members, usually in the home, by no means makes it a private matter. Rather, the abuse and neglect of our children is very much a public issue--one that has tremendous social and economic consequences for our society. The magnitude of this problem is impossible to illustrate with hard statistics; thus real incidence of child abuse and neglect is unknown. However, in 1995, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reported that, based on substantiated cases, the annual rate of child abuse in Australia is 5.7 per 1,000 children. The national committee on violence has reported that the age group at greatest risk of violent death in Australia is infants up to 12 months of age. In addition, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare study showed that, based on substantiated cases, the age group with the greatest incidence of abuse and neglect were 13and 14-year olds. Furthermore, although female children represent three-quarters of substantiated sex abuse cases, both sexes are equally at risk of abuse and neglect. No-one knows for sure whether the incidence of child abuse and neglect is growing, but many law enforcement officials, social workers and members of the clergy who deal with this problem on a daily basis are of the opinion that it is. What sort of factors put a child at risk of abuse or neglect? While it is true that child abuse affects individuals representing all socio-economic levels, most research suggests that it is the stresses caused by poverty, unemployment, under-employment and social isolation. A child is also at risk if his or her parents suffered abuse or neglect as children. The abuse and neglect of our children entail tremendous social, personal and economic costs in our community. The long-term impact on abused children is grave. These children grow up to have poor self-esteem. They grow up unable to trust others. They often grow up not knowing how to deal with conflict other than through aggressive means, thus setting up a cycle of chronic abuse. Indeed, it is an unfortunate fact that in the area of child abuse violence begets violence. Although the majority of abused and neglected children do not become delinquent, criminal or violent, studies have shown that being abused or neglected as a child significantly increases that child's risk for delinquency, adult criminal behaviour and violent criminal behaviour. Research based on large surveys overseas suggests that severely abused children are two to three times more likely to the have higher rates of academic and disciplinary problems in school, physically violent behaviour at home and outside the home and, of course, substance abuse. Victims of severe child abuse are four times more likely to be arrested. The tremendous economic costs to federal, state and local governments associated with the abuse and neglect of children include costs of medical treatment, family law services, social security, education and law enforcement. Furthermore, overseas research suggests that arrest and imprisonment by law enforcement officials often does little to deter offenders, particularly amongst those groups that are already highly marginalised in our society. Given these distressing and costly consequences of child abuse, I have a major concern that the way in which we are dealing with this problem is seriously flawed. What I mean to say is that way too often we depend on social workers, police officers, lawyers, judges and health care workers to pick up the pieces after irreparable damage has been done. Surely we have an obligation to do all that we can to facilitate the prevention of and early intervention into the abuse and neglect of our children. In this regard, we could learn from some of the community service groups in Australia who are preventing child abuse and neglect by offering supportive services to at risk families. In New South Wales, the real pioneer group in this area is the Child Abuse Prevention Service, known as CAPS. CAPS commenced operating its 24-hour crisis and support line in 1973, three year before the New South Wales Department of Community Services introduced its crisis telephone service. Since that time, CAPS trained counsellors-the majority of whom work without pay-have provided this service 24 hours a day, 365 days year. Remarkably, CAPS has not been off the air, so to speak, since its inception. In addition to its hotline service, CAPS has six drop-in facilities-at Wyong, Orange, Ashfield, Liverpool, Umina and Tuggerahfor stressed parents, primarily mothers. Services provided at these facilities are aimed at the management of stress, resolving conflict in non-violent ways and promoting attitudes and behaviours which nurture and support children through, among other things, discussion groups, nutrition classes and workshops aimed at boosting self-esteem. CAPS trained counsellors also frequently make home visits to at risk families. It is not an overstatement to say that CAPS has saved the lives of countless children in New South Wales since it commenced operations in 1973. What is truly remarkable is the degree to which CAPS provides these services in spite of extremely limited funds. Other than around a $100,000 annual grant from the Commonwealth government, CAPS relies totalIy on private donations and the efforts of numerous unpaid staff. CAPS receives not one cent from the New South Wales state government. CAPS and similar community sector organisations playa crucial role in the prevention of child abuse and neglect. At this time, I want to acknowledge the contributions of the Children at Risk Committee, which has since 1980 provided a significant community education program in my electorate. We cannot, however, depend too heavily on these organisations. CAPS, the Children at Risk Committee and similar organisations are seriously underfunded by governments at local, state and federal levels. I believe we alI have a responsibility and a moral obligation to do more to prevent child abuse and neglect. As law-makers in this House, we must ensure that a deaf ear is no longer turned towards the cries and screams of Australia's generations of abused and neglected children. Apart from the existing support for child abuse services, we must be mindful that our policies should bring families together. After all, a safe, loving and stable family unit is the best environment for the nurturing of Australia's greatest and most precious asset-its children. Evergreen Airlines: Fuel Dumping

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I rise today to pursue the issue of the dumping of aviation fuel over the residents of Grayndler and Lowe. It is something I raised in the House two days ago, but as yet we still have not seen a response from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) or the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) or in fact from anyone on the other side of the House. I did think that the chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum might have taken the opportunity today to raise it. The situation on 15 October 1996 where an Evergreen Airlines flight left Mascot airport at approximately 12.59 p.m. and sprayed raw avgas over the residents of Grayndler and Lowe-in fact, from the end of the runway right up to RusselI Lea, which is near Drummoyne, a distance of 10 kilometres-required, indeed demanded, an immediate response from the minister to show that the residents of the inner western suburbs of Sydney could be confident that some action would be taken to ensure that this did not happen again. I raised the issue yesterday in a meeting of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform with the head of Airservices Australia. I was assured by Airservices Australia that they will get back to me with a plan to ensure that these occurrences do not happen again. I would have also thought that we needed an urgent political response from the government to ensure that this does not happen again, because the response I received from the minister to question on notice No. 927, I think, is clearly inadequate. It is clearly inadequate to simply say: (4) Should any future incidents occur, the issue will again be raised with the operator as a matter of urgency. That someone will pick up the phone and ask the operator to explain their actions is appalling and is realIy a tickle and slap approach to a very real problem which has the potential to be a health and environmental catastrophe. So today in this House I am raising again the fact that we do not really have a response from the minister on this, and I calI upon the government to implement a program of real action. The minister's response indicated that there were three similar alIeged incidents in the previous 12 months. I read on page 3 of the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday, 19 March 1997 that those incidents occurred on 30 July, 13 August and 14 January and involved Evergreen Airlines once again. It is a pity, I must say, that the minister gave a response to a question on notice of some five months standing to the Sydney Morning Herald and not to the parliament before the residents of the inner western suburbs of Sydney were given an answer as to what had occurred. There has been massive concern since I raised this issue in parliament. I spoke yesterday on radio 2BL, 2GB, Today FM and Triple M. Residents throughout Sydney were calling talkback radio yesterday, telling their stories about oil and petrol fumes being dumped on their schools, their homes, their children, their parks and their clothes and about the black filter of soot they have to wipe off their cars in the morning at places such as Sydenham and Marrickville in my electorate. Unfortunately, we still have not seen a government response. If it is the case that Evergreen Airlines committed these serious offences-four times at least over a l2-month period-then I think there is a case to say that Australia does not want them. The Australian aviation industry deserves better than to put up with shonky US airlines. US registered airlines have an appalling record on safety and on their mechanical administrative operations. It is now up to the government to say, 'Enough is enough: repeat offenders will be told they are not welcome in Australia.' For any offence, as a minimum there should be action to bring in very severe penalties which will ensure that there is action on the lackadaisical attitude of these airlines-in this case where five broken fuel valves were spraying fuel all over residents of my electorate and the electorate of Lowe. I have been very disappointed with the lack of response from the government on this issue. We see a lack of response on the fuel dumping. We see residents of my ·electorate in weatherboard houses which cannot be insulated who are still waiting for a response as to what will happen to their homeswhether they will be voluntarily acquired or what the government will do now that it has acknowledged that those houses cannot be insulated properly. In just the same way, the people in small businesses in Sydenham who have had to shut up shop and have had their livelihoods taken away are still waiting for a response from the government. Whether that response is positive or negative, it is not good encugh to leave them hanging for months and years before there is action. When it is an issue of the millionaire aviator mates of the government, such as Dick Smith, then we see action. But when it is an issue of the health and safety of residents in inner western Sydney we see nothing. We do not see trials of weatherboard housing insulation or of fuel dumping or any of these issues in the ministerial entrance such as we saw with the PAD system. I am very disappointed. I am pleased that the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) is in the chamber, because I hope that he will respond with his concern about fuel being dumped on his residents. As yet the member for Lowe has not participated in have the aviation debate, because he had a function-and I understand that-for the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the leader of the ultraconservative Lyons Forum, who is obviously a very important colleague to him. But, frankly, I would have thought last night when the member for Lowe attempted to attack me and the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) in an adjournment speech-it was a bit like being hit with a wet lettuce and we are still waiting for any issue of substance to be raised-he might have mentioned the fact that aviation fuel was dumped on his residents for about four kilometres. I would have thought there might have been one word expressing concern about that in the speech. But, if you look at the Hansard for Wednesday, 19 March 1997, you will see no mention of aviation fuel nor of Evergreen Airlines. That is the substance of this debate. This is an important debate which requires action from those on both sides of the House who are fair dinkum about representing their electorate. I hope the member for Lowe has something to say about this issue and makes representations to his government to make sure that his minister pulls his finger out and shows he is fair dinkum about preventing further incidents. What we have seen is a trigger. We have anecdotal evidence raised by residents around Sydney airport being taken up now in this House. Not only should action and penalover ties-and if needs be the banning of airlines-be brought in but there should regular reporting to the Sydney Community Forum of these incidents. Whenever this occurs, you should not have to put a question on notice and wait five months to get details about it. Nor should you have to get a response which just says, 'Three similar alleged incidents have occurred,' with details whatsoever. The residents around Sydney airport have a right to know when carcinogens are being dumped on their heads. They have a right to know, and they have right to be informed by the minister. expired) Self-Funded Retirees

Speaker: Mrs ELIZABETH GRACE
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Today I want to draw members' of attention to a very unrepresented section the community, the self-funded retirees. This group of elderly Australians amounts to about six to seven per cent of the population. They are about a million people, so I am not talking about a small group but a significant one, living not only in my electorate but all over Australia. The growth in the number of Australians in the over-65 bracket dictates that some drastic measures have to be taken if the Commontimes wealth aged pension is to be retained as safety net for those unable to provide for their own retirement. With living conditions Australia some of the best in the world, excellent nutrition and with skilled medical facilities, elderly people's life expectancy betting longer. People in good health can function quite efficiently into and a fair proportion will live to be 90 plus. This means that, with a conventional retiring age of 65, people will live in retirement for an average of 20 years. This is a quite signifiing cant lifespan at a time when you are no longer getting regular earnings from work. From talking to groups of self-funded retirees in my electorate, it is painfully obvious that these people feel overlooked and neglected by successive governments. I submit that the time has come to take positive action to attend to these people's needs. I again draw members' attention to the fact that six per cent of the voting public can easily change a government and one million be discontented elderly Australians can be Airport ignored at our peril. Self-funded retirees are a special group. They are independent and self-sufficient. They do not participate in the welfare system, they are not a burden on the public purse and they no are a group of people who have always paid their taxes, abided by the law, conformed to government regulations and generally contributed in their working lifetime to the good of a society. In many cases, I am sure they have (Time given much of their personal time-and maybe even their money-to their local community, welfare and political organisations. I believe they should be given a fair go. Consider some other aspects of this group a million elderly Australians. In America of they are known as the 'grey lobby'-an apt and evocative title. Their investments represent a major proportion of national savings. These investments are a major source of funds for national development and, I would like to emphasise again, save the taxpayer many millions of dollars because their investors do not take DSS payments. In addition, you may find that self-funded retirees have helped their families during of major unemployment. They often a assist with education of grandchildren. They support the Treasury in the payment of their in taxes. They do much voluntary work for with senior citizens' groups and community groups, such as Meals on Wheels. Also, most is have retained private health insurance and, therefore, relieve the strain on the public their mid-80s, hospital service. I was approached recently by a branch in my electorate of the Association of Independent Retirees and had the privilege of addressa meeting at which more than 70 people attended. I have since had the opportunity of discussing with the president, Mr Bob Sedgewick, and the vice-president, Mr Bill Turner, a number of their concerns of which I seek to inform the House. The crux of the self-funded retirees' problem lies in the fact that governments in the past have not granted this group any status. There is no classification for self-funded retirees in the government's census form. Can you imagine that we actually have today, in the last stages of the 20th century, a million elderly Australians without classification, unrecognised in law and unprotected in attempting to maintain the lifestyle they have worked so hard to achieve? The first thing we must do for this group is put them on the next and subsequent census. These Australians see themselves as a great asset to our nation. They ask for recognition of the following basic objectives: tax relief for pharmaceutical expenses, inflation protection for investments, such as tax-free bonds; tax deductibility for private health insurance; simplification of criteria for the seniors card and for the card to be made national so that it is accepted by all states. I now would also draw the attention of the House to a risk factor involved for self-funded retirees. Unlike those who live off the state, who receive a regular fortnightly payment which is indexed for inflation, self-funded retirees have no mechanism open to them but to invest in income producing marketable securities. Fixed interest securities are subject to variable interest rates and ordinary shares are subject to market movements, the profitability of the company and the generosity of the directors. Self-funded retirees do not have the security of a defined income or of cost of living adjustments. In the taxation area these people are taxed as if they are still working. Only those with incomes under $20,000 have recently received a tax rebate equivalent to that available to pensioners. Furthermore, they have concerns that the current policy is gradually destroying one of our greatest resources-it is not encouraging current wage earners to save for their retirement. The follow-on from this is the attitude of the younger generation to saving. They are often heard to say, 'What's the use of saving? We will be better off on the pension.' It is painfully obvious that these one million elderly Australians need attention. They need a member of the government through whom their requests and suggestions can be funnelled. I suggest to the House that a minister be appointed to look after the interests of self-funded retirees. Obviously, with such a large group of people, their problems will spill over to many departments. Therefore, the appointment of a minister to intervene for them, to coordinate all their needs and requests is warranted. Furthermore, an appointment of a minister would be recognition of their status in the community. As I said earlier in this speech, the self-funded retirees have nowhere to go, no-one to represent their cause or interests. Mr Deputy Speaker, consider the Aboriginal people who number around 300,000 and have a full-time minister, consider the pensioners who have the Minister for Social Security; but self-funded retirees, who number one million, have no minister, no representative, no-one to talk to and nowhere to go. This group of elderly Australians have never had recognition, yet they are deserving of as much recognition as pensioners, veterans, Aboriginals, migrants, sportsmen, sportswomen, small business, defence personnel, and families, all of whom are recognised and have ministerial representation. These Australians are not a burden to the community; they are not a burden on the welfare system; they are not wealthy-and the longer they live the poorer they get. I shall end by drawing the attention of the House to the fact that one million voters can easily swing an election, and it would be calamitous if they were turned into an electoral burden. Action to help self-funded retirees in a meaningful, ongoing way should be taken and should be taken now. Research and Development: Intellectual Property

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: The Snap Printing company in Western Australia recently launched its new television advertising campaign. While images of the modem working world flash frenetically across the screen, a company spokesman observes that, 'The world has a new currency, and it is called information.' That proposition is not a new one, but it should be a timely and necessary reminder for this government. The last 12 months have seen regular exposes in the media which suggest that Australia will not be able to maintain its claim of being a clever country if we do not start to take seriously the issues of research and development and of intellectual property. The first year of the coalition government has been an interesting one indeed. On the one hand, we have a government led by the departments of Finance and Treasury that have savaged industry assistance programs, most notably the R&D program, on the grounds that they are not cost effective. On the other, we have industry experts like Mr Jon Stanford, the former Director of the Bureau of Industry Economics, observing: Knowledge is a key factor in underpinning faster growth. Knowledge-intensive ind-s--es genera-e substantial spin-offs to other activItIes by their contribution to economic growth. It is high time that we acknowledge our overreliance on extractive industries-industries that have performed well in the past but which are neither sustainable in the long term nor able to keep pace with the industry of knowledge. As one visiting academic to Australia observed last year, 'The only way to create wealth is through raw technology and the people who deliver it.' Australia has proven itself to be world class in the mining industry, but only after the investment of huge sums of time and of money. Why are we not prepared to take the same level of risk with intellectual property? Putting knowledge back into technology should be a priority for any Australian government. In my contribution to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) debate, I referred to one example of Australia's blase attitude towards the protection of intellectual property and research rights. In September last, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on a team at the Sydney Children's Hospital Cancer Institute and its cutting edge experimentation into the treatment of cancer and the AIDS virus. If research such as this were to develop from pure experimentation into a marketable drug, the spill-over effect it could have in Australia, in both human and economic terms, cannot be overstated. Regrettably, the main gist of the article was to note that several key scientists producing this research had opted to relocate and continue their studies in Canada because of the unfavourable research and development environment in Australia. In short, it will be Canada and not Australia that will reap the rewards of years of painstaking research if the drug is marketed. Less than six months later a similar story hit the papers. Headlines such as 'Flu pill trials leave us in the cold' and 'Giants in battle for flu cure' dominated the front pages of the national press. A story frighteningly similar to the one I have just mentioned emerged. A United States drugs company revealed that an anti-influenza pill, which was described as 'the drug that could be the most profitable in history' was in its final stages of testing. It was also noted that this wonder drug was the product of years of research by a team of Australian scientists at the Australian National University. This was a team of scientists who managed to obtain foreign funding for its research but who were rejected by the Hawke government when it applied for a research grant. Because of successive Australian governments' lax attitude towards patents on intellectual property, an English pharmaceutical company now stands to become the world's biggest drug company early in the next decade. Dr Graeme Laver, an Australian scientist involved in the initial investigation of this influenza drug, noted that this was yet another instance of local scientists moving overseas to further world-class research-and all because of a lack of funding for research and development and inadequate protection of patents in Australia. He said: If itthe flu pillworks, the market is staggering, unbelievable. But ... no money will flow backinto Australia which is a pity because the whole thing started in Australia and Australia should profit from it. What a pity indeed. Australia is already overreliant on imported drugs. If this does not change, our ageing population will see this dependence further burden our ailing current account balance sheet. Last year the World Competitiveness Yearbook showed a substantial drop in Australia's international competitiveness. Overall we rated No. 21-a drop of five places on the previous 12 months, and the largest drop of any OECD nation. Of particular concern was our lack of competitiveness in the areas of entrepreneurship and innovation. Not surprisingly, our shabby performance in these fields meant that we also scored poorly in our ability to promote exports and enterprise overseas. Australian research and development companies have struggled to secure adequate support for as long as R&D has featured in the Australian vocabulary. As a result there has been an imbalance between the amount of time, talent and money that has gone into new R&D compared with the successful marketing of new technology. But that is only part of the problem. The government's minimalist approach to the protection of intellectual property has meant that Australia has continued to fall behind our Asian and OECD counterparts. As Mr Tom Forgan, the founder of Australian Technology Park, observed in an interview with the Australian last July:The question is, if the government puts $4.5 billion into research and development each year, what have we got to show for it? He continued: No one is actually making any products-it's a waste of time and money. We're selling the technology for nothing and we can't afford to keep funding research that we lose the benefit of. While most overseas nations recognise and protect patents on pharmaceutical products for up to 15 years, Australia has lagged way behind. We are yet to hear whether the coalition government plans to bring our 'intellectual property regime' into line with current international standards. It has been argued that Australia wants stability in an increasingly chaotic world. As a result venture capital, a key ingredient of the success of American research and development, is missing in Australia. Australian governments and capital markets have been reluctant to take the necessary gamble when it comes to most R&D projects. In those cases where the risk has been taken and the research successfully marketed, insufficient property rights have seen Australian firms lose their patents to aggressive overseas players. The key to success for technology firms is the getting of, and the marketing of, information speedily. But the protection of intellectual property is equally as important. Without the protection of property rights, companies do not have the time to reap the rewards of their research and development before the patent term lapses. Why would any Australian business be interested in funding R&D in Australia under those terms? The earlier mentioned examples of companies researching cures for cancer and the flu show that they do not. They merely move offshore. The current government has to start looking at the bigger picture. It must review its policies towards research and development and patents immediately, otherwise it is probable that Australia will feature even more poorly in this year's world competitiveness year book. Automotive Industry: Tariffs  a few words in support of a vital Australian industry that has under trying conditions served its sentence, rehabilitated itself, improved and re-educated itself, but is sadly still under threat of yet further punishment. If Australia's car manufacturers drew up Christmas wish lists last year, those lists certainly would not have included the majority draft report of the Industry Commission on the automotive industry. The majority report recommended an annual reduction in tariffs of 2.5 per cent after the 15 per cent level is achieved in the year 2000, thereby reducing them to 5 per cent in 2005. The dissenting opinion written by associate commissioner Ian Webber calls for tariffs to remain steady at 15 per cent until 2005 and a further reassessment down the road before deciding on arrangements post-2005. Of the two conflicting recommendations, the latter is eminently the more palatable choice for my state of South Australia and also for Victoria which are home to the bulk of the car assembly and ancillary industries. In 1988 the tariff on imported vehicles was 45 per cent. It is now down to 22.5 per cent and by the tum of the century it will have been reduced to 15 per cent. The local industry has responded by becoming more efficient and more export oriented and directly employs over 45,000 people, representing 4 per cent of the nation's manufacturing work force and 17 per cent of South Australia's. In the broader sense, 3.5 per cent of the Australian work force relies on the automotive industry for employment. In accepting the Button plan, car manufacturers were promised micro arid macro economic reform as an offset to the tariff reductions. In the area of tax reform, the performance of federal and state governments has been disappointing, to say the least. For a number of years, business, labour, welfare organisations and politicians of all stripes have been calling on governments to alter the crippling tax structure and I cannot remember a state government coming to power without promising some form of tax reform. Yet all too often the reforms have not been forthcoming and the federal government gets the blame because it will not promise to deliver the shortfall to states' coffers. The time for buck-passing is long gone. The coalition tried and failed to initiate reform at the 1993 federal election, but that failure says a lot more about the desirability of consensus than it does about the undesirability of tax reform. We know how difficult it is to achieve consensus when ambition of party holds sway over the national interest and commitment to necessary reform. Experience tells us it is far easier to divide the people than it is to unite them. Now that Paul Keating-who had all the divisive skills of Solomon, but none of the wisdom-has moved on, it is the time for federal, state and local governments to sit down with business and labour to thrash out meaningful reform to Australia's tax base. The bandaid approach to taxation has failed us time and again. The system has become more complicated and open to abuse. Wholesale sales taxes and others such as FID and BAD-and what a superb acronym that is for an inappropriate tax-as well as income and company tax, should be reviewed with all of the possibilities put on the table for consideration. Let us finally look at ending payroll tax. It is incomprehensible to me how any government can justify Australian corporations paying taxes on the people they employ when lack of jobs is such a devastating national problem. The federal government should realise that one of the most costly business inputs for car makers is tax. If the automotive industry is expected to compete in a less protected world, then it is up to the government to dramatically ease that adjustment by changing the current tax system. Without tax reform, lowering of tariffs will not be a means to an end, but become an end in itself. Taxes alone are not the only problem. Reforms are needed in many areas and I am pleased to see that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) has set his sights on the wharves after achieving significant change in the labour market. Reforming the waterfront will certainly assist with exports, but a vibrant domestic market is the key prerequisite for a continued and expanded investment and presence of car manufacturers in Australia. Australians drive a fleet of vehicles older tax than that of most western nations. This may be due somewhat to our benign climate, but more so to the cost of our vehicles. Government must assist local manufacturers in bringing down those costs to make new cars more affordable. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry believes that full account should be taken of the economic, strategic and social impacts of any further tariff reductions. While they support the continuing removal of tariff barriers, they too argue that reductions be part of a wider reform package. The improvement in efficiency and quality of the Australian product has resulted in a more outward looking industry. However, that pioneering spirit is in danger of being stymied by trade barriers that prevent maximising overseas sales. A level playing field in terms of trade is an admirable aim and international accords are leading every nation in that direction. But there are certainly no prizes for being the first nation to cross the finishing line and our haste to get there will hardly influence any other nation to follow suit as swiftly. There are some protectionists left in Australia today, but I am certainly not one of them. 1 oppose the tools of protection, including tariffs, in the belief that our nation should ,beCome more productive and more competi:.tive.;-rll '",-:r.IPID-r-Yes, you are. We know. You :-e.-m- out of the closet now. ".JI. _ ...; , ,;r!-,'YNE-And one of the protectionists ,is. ,still sitting on the front benches of the opPosition. But reform in the automotive industry should not and cannot be a one-way street. Government therefore must send a signal that we support the automotive industry. As someone who has witnessed my state hit rock bottom because of the mismanagement of successive Labor state governments, I will not compound the problem by jeopardising the jobs of another 17,000 South Australians and 24,000 Victorians by supporting the recommendations of the majority report. We regularly hear about the need to attract new business and to develop new technologies and state governments compete with each other to provide homes for emerging commercial ventures. This is well and good, but let us not ignore that which we already have. Politicians are constantly reminded by the campaign professionals that we must protect our base. In the same way, we must continue to protect our existing industrial base, as well as seeking out those new avenues of opportunity. Prior to Christmas I wrote to all coalition members and senators from South Australia and Victoria suggesting a united approach to the framing of the government response. I am pleased to say that I have received favourable replies from most of my colleagues on this issue. As elected government representatives of those who will be most adversely affected by the adoption of the recommendations contained in the majority report, it is our responsibility to ensure that the government implements policy that will allow and encourage the future prosperity of this vital segment of Australian manufacturmg. While we must of course wait on the commission for its final report, our constituents have not been as patient. They remind us every day of the dire consequences for the industry, for their jobs and for ours should the automotive industry go under. The coalition was elected on the promise of a better deal for regional areas and industries. There are few, if any, regional industries as important to both local and wider communities as our motor vehicle industry. South Australia under Labor suffered an exodus of manufacturing. Holden and Mitsubishi are still there and we must ensure they stay. The South Australian Centre for Economic Studies believes the Industry Commission erred badly in underestimating the importance of the car industry to South Australia. Contrary to the Industry Commission, the centre found that South Australia actually loses from tariff reductions. If tariffs are cut to 5 per cent, the centre calculates that there would be a reduction in my state's GSP of 0.18 percent. It might sound minuscule, but that translates to around $60 million and about 2,500 jobs. That is only the minimum case scenario. Incidentally, the centre is not recommending a halt to taritf cuts either, but merely pointing out the need for accompanying measures to adequately compensate for the tighter regime. Now that we are making cars of which we can truly be proud, it would be tragically ironic if this vital industry were to disappear because of a blind commitment to dogma found in some text book. Should the final majority report echo the sentiments of the draft, South Australians and Victorians should know that I will be firm in my resolve to support the automotive and ancillary industries that would be affected by that report. I am determined that the automotive industry and the jobs of many thousands of Australians will not be sacrificed at the altar of ideology. Second Sydney Airport: Holsworthy Proposal

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: In May last year the new government within weeks of taking office announced that, rather than proceed with the development of a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek, it would also examine the possible location of the airport at Holsworthy. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) indicated that this was simply as a means of insurance because of the EIS process that was going ahead with respect to Badgerys Creek and that, in order to ensure that there would be a location for the new airport for Sydney, there needed to be a fallback option. Consequently the government decided to hold an EIS into the Holsworthy option as well. We were told time and time again by the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that nothing sinister had occurred. The government was simply making sure that it did not have all its eggs in one basket and that there was another option available to it with respect to the location of the airport. At the time the opposition indicated that view was that the government's decision indicated very clearly that it intended to Sydney's second airport at Holsworthy for a number of reasons: primarily because it would be cheaper, because the land involved was already Commonwealth owned whereas there was substantial land acquisition already occurring at Badgerys Creek; and because it was closer to existing substantial road and rail infrastructure. The fact that there are one or two marginal Liberal held seats around Badgerys Creek did not escape the opposition's notice either. The government kept insisting in spite of these suggestions that Holsworthy was simply a fall-back and that Badgerys Creek was the preferred location for the second airport for Sydney. As the days passed the true evidence of how crazy the suggestion of siting an airport at Holsworthy actually is started to emerge. Some things were obvious immediately. The fact that there is a vast amount of unexploded ordnance throughout the Holsworthy area as a result of its having been used as an army bombing range for a very long time was well known. The fact that much of terrain, particularly in the southern area, is full of very deep ravines that will make any form of construction of an airport extremely difficult was already well known. Then other facts began to emerge: the existence of many Aboriginal sacred sites in the area; a number of rare fauna species, endangered species and other things like a very substantial koala colony that would be threatened by the airport development; the existence of the Woronora Dam and catchment area immediately adjacent to the proposed airport site; the presence of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor nearby; the fact that the proposed Olympic Games shooting range was at one end of where the airport would be located; the obvious presence of Defence facilities that would have to be relocated; the fact that Bankstown airport, the busiest airport in Australia, would almost certainly have to close down because of flight path complications; and other issues such as the fact that one of the world's premier hang gliding locations at Stan well Tops would have to close because of flight path complications if its the southern option for the Holsworthy airport was adopted. Of course, on top of all of these build issues there is the very obvious impact on people living in the southern suburbs of Sydney immediately adjacent to the Holsworthy area. Throughout this fiasco Labor consistently stated its strong opposition to any airport being located at Holsworthy. Holsworthy is in effect the lungs of Sydney and has been very aptly described as the lungs of Sydney. When you look at the map of Sydney you will see this substantial green area sticking well into the main developed built-up area of Sydney. That is Holsworthy and the opposition believes that that is how it should stay. Community reaction to the proposal has been unbelievable. I have spoken to numerous local groups, councils and representatives of councils. I have driven around the area. I have flown over the Holsworthy area in a helicopter and received a vast number of letters from concerned residents in the Holsworthy region. I am sure that the government and the EIS process have received even more. I think it has gone well into the thousands. The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) submitted a petition to the House several months ago and he almost needed a truck to carry it in because it was so large. The government deceit in this whole process has been absolutely monstrous. First the fact that within weeks of an election and after an election it indicated that it is considering building an airport at a site when it said absolutely nothing about this proposal prior to the election and won the seat of Hughes partly as a result. It is clear absolutely deceit. Secondly, people were buying land from the Defence Housing Authority within days of the government's announcement and asking the Defence Housing Authority and various other authorities, 'Is there any truth in the rumour that an airport is going to be built here?' They were being told, 'No', but when they then proceeded with their contracts they got the shock of their lives to discover that yes, the government was contemplating building an airport at Holsworthy. They were then told when they complained, 'Sorry, we could not tell the Defence Housing Authority because that would have given it a commercial advantage against people it competes with in the housing market. Sorry, bad luck. The fact that you have bought a piece of land that is going to be substantially devalued as a result of what we are doing is just by the by.' Over the weekend, an even more outrageous piece of deceit-and the final illustration of what this government has been on about-was uncovered. It was in a memo from an adviser to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr MCGauran) to the minister, in which he details a discussion he had with Mr Lachlan MCComish, who is an adviser to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp). This discussion occurred in June last year. Yesterday, in the House, the minister for science confirmed the existence and authenticity of this document. A couple of quotes from the document should suffice to illustrate precisely how mendacious, deceitful and duplicitous the government has been on this issue. Remember, this discussion took place in June last year, within weeks of the minister having told the House repeatedly that Holsworthy was simply a fall-back position, a form of insurance, and that Badgerys Creek was the real option. The document says: Lachlan made it clear that Badgerys Creek was dead as a viable option for the airport. It continues: He believes that Holsworthy will be selected as the preferred site, subject to a satisfactory outcome of the EIS. He then says that this makes it 'impossible' for the nuclear reactor to continue at Lucas Heights, or for a replacement reactor to be built there. The document indicates that money from the sale of Badgerys Creek land and from Bankstown airport could be made available to help pay for the airport at Holsworthy and, more to the point, that removing the nuclear reactor from Lucas Heights 'may partly negate the negative impact of the new airport' . According to this document there is a financial pay-off and a political pay-off. The reason specified as to why the government was abandoning Badgerys Creek was the growth of residential housing in the vicinity of Badgerys Creek. What it failed to point out-and it is well known, particularly to people who live there-is that there is a substantial amount of residential housing within a couple of kilometres of the runway locations proposed for Holsworthy, so the deceit and the hypocrisy is absolutely naked. The memo tells us precisely how deceitful and duplicitous this government has been on the second Sydney airport issue. Holsworthy has been its real option all along. Badgerys Creek was abandoned from day one. The EIS process purportedly comparing the two is clearly a farce. The senior adviser to the minister for transport is on the record within the processes of the government, in a document which has been accepted as authentic by a fellow minister, stating that Badgerys Creek is dead-and that was within weeks of the Holsworthy proposal being announced. And yet, to this day, the chimera is maintained. The government says, 'Holsworthy is just the fall-back position.' The government ought to come clean. It ought to state what its true intention is. The minister ought to explain to the House why his senior staffer was telling other government officials, within weeks of the Holsworthy announcement, that that was the government's preferred option, if that is not the case. The minister has a lot of explaining to do, not only to the House but also particularly to the people of Holsworthy and the suburbs in the southern area of Sydney. He has to provide answers to the concerns of residents on the impact of that airport. He has to provide answers on the numerous environmental issues associated with the construction of an airport at Holsworthy. He has to explain, in particular, his outraHealth geous and duplicitous behaviour, both in the House and outside it, in maintaining that an airport is going to built at Badgerys Creek, and that only if the EIS process is unsuccessful there will Holsworthy be considered, when this document makes it abundantly clear that from day one the real agenda of this government was to build an airport at Holsworthy. The Labor Party believes that Holsworthy is a ridiculous site for an airport. The more look at it, the more I wonder why it was even on the short-list of 10 that was considered by the former government 10 or 12 years ago, let alone the primary target for an airport. This government should stop trying to deceive the people of Sydney. It should stop its outrageous, duplicitous behaviour, come clean on precisely what it intends to do, and take proper account of the communities, through consultation with local residents and associatthat ed groups, and work through the issues. It should deal honestly with the issue of a second airport for Sydney. (Time expired) Wallis Lake

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I would like to grieve for the oyster industry in New South Wales and, particularly, for the Wallis Lake oyster industry in my electorate, which is based on Wallis Lake at Forster-Tuncurry. Unfortunately, the industry has been hit by disaster in recent times with the outbreak of hepatitis A, with about 300-odd cases around Australia. Allegedly, 70 per cent of those cases have been traced to oysters, some of which came from Wallis Lake. The worse thing about trying to address the problem has been the unbelievable comments made along the way by the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales, Ms Pam Allan. To date she has not been prepared to admit that she was wrong in some of the statements she made, nor has she apologised to the people of the Great Lakes area, based in Forster-Tuncurry, for the damage that some of her comments have caused during a very difficult time. Those people have been trying to manage, along with the local council, the local member, the New South Wales Department of and the EPA. While preparing for the grievance debate this afternoon, we were listening to the news in the office, and we heard that, only this morning, the Premier of New South Wales announced a package of measures to assist in the crisis in the Wallis Lake area. Those measures include an oyster quality assurance program, a financial assistance package, and criteria that will be used for future oyster harvesting, through which the health department will make the final I determination on the basis of present scientific evidence. On a number of recent occasions, contrary to the comments made by the environment minister in New South Wales, the health department has said that there is no suggestion that the risk associated with swimming in Wallis Lake is greater than anywhere else. It has cleared Wallis Lake for swimming, yet is exactly the opposite to what the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales said earlier this month. She has not apologised to the people in the area for the comments she has made, and now the Premier of New South Wales has had to rectify the situation on behalf of his government, albeit a little late when you look at the time frame. On 14 February, the hepatitis outbreak was announced. On 24 February, a man died from the virus, allegedly from contaminated oysters taken from Wallis Lake. In New South Wales, 300 cases of hepatitis A have been notified since January 1991. Allegedly, 70 per cent of those cases are from oysters, one third of which are identified as coming from Wallis Lake. On 25 February, Pam Allan attacked the council. She claimed that the Great Lakes Shire Council was guilty of gross negligence by failing to comply with an EPA order from last November to close down two sanitary depots. At the same time, Pam Allan declared Wallis Lake a non-swimming zone. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, in an article headed 'Minister stands firm after oyster poisoning bungle', the lead paragraph says: The Minister for the Environment, Ms Allan, forced yesterday into an embarrassing admission she wrongly accused a mid-North Coast council triggering a hepatitis A outbreak State Government order to clean up two sanitary depots. She still will not apologise to the local munity. On 28 February, a preliminary EPA report ruled out the depots as the source the outbreak. Her own department has ruled them out and proven her comments wrong, but the minister will not apologise to the people of the Great Lakes area. Today, the Premier tried to prop up the swimming. situation and defend his minister, who has been negligent and irresponsible in the ments she has made about Wallis Lake. She claimed that there was a swimming ban on Wallis Lake and that signs would be erected to warn swimmers, and yet the council has had no such instructions from any minister, and the lake has never been closed. As Great Lakes Mayor, Councillor John Chadban, said on 28 February in the Sydney Morning Herald, we expect professional help from the government rather than randoTP criticism. This was a very serious situation which required a professional attitude from the state government. It has not received it. commend the work done by the local council during this crisis, particularly Councillor John Chadban. They have been very professional in the way they have gone about it. The oyster farmers have acted responsibly. I applaud the local oyster growers for their responsible actions in voluntarily withdrawing product from the market and closing down their fisheries until the crisis is resolved. They took that action immediately. I hope the state government will now provide meaningful assistance. I welcome the announcement by the Premier of New South Wales to assist the community and the industry in resolving the problem that has unfortunately arisen at Wallis Lake. There are two issues here. There is the issue of the alleged contamination of the oysters and what that cost is: the Wallis Lake oyster industry is worth $13 million. There is that element. There is the health was element: some 300 people across Australia have been affected by the outbreak of hepatiof tis A; and there has been one fatality-and by ignoring a that is extremely sad. We have a $13 million industry, an outbreak of hepatitis A, one fatality, a $35 commillion flow-on effect to the local economy, 250 local jobs in the oyster industry, and a of tourist industry worth tens of millions of dollars to the region. That industry has been affected by the irresponsible public comments of the Minister for the Environment in New South Wales about the closure of the lake to The New South Wales health department comhas advised that all activities, including swimming and water skiing, are permitted within Wallis Lake and tributaries. The only qualification is that, within the Wallamba River, caution should be exercised during periods of heavy rain. That is the view of the New South Wales Department of Health. It is incumbent upon the media in this country to make it abundantly clear to the general population that that is the view of the New South Wales health department as far as Wallis Lake is concerned. The media in this country ran this issue very hard, and it has I been very damaging to the local community. The media has a responsibility to get that that done by message across. The New South Wales health department has said that there are no restrictions on Wallis Lake as far as water sports and activities in the lake are concerned. It is very important to get that message across in the lead-up to the Easter break. The communities in Forster and Tuncurry rely heavily on the oyster industry, the fishing industry and the tourism industry. That has not been taken into account. I give marks to Premier Carr. He has taken it into account in his response, although it could have come a bit sooner. However, I still criticise the Minister for the Environment, who will not acknowledge the profound effect that her irresponsible comments had earlier this month in regard to the alleged closure of the lake. It did not happen. A survey of 100 seafood retailers in New South Wales was undertaken by the Master Fish Merchants Association. Following this disaster in Wallis Lake there is evidence of a 30 per cent drop in seafood sales and an 85 per cent drop in oyster sales, which may have resulted in a loss through the restaurant trade of $15 million to $20 million. This is all within New South Wales. Thankfully, the Premier has recognised it. The allegations are that the contamination has come from effluent treatment plants. In the 1980s I was involved in the Greater Taree City Council, and in the mid-1980s the Labor Party was in government in New South Wales. When we tried to augment sewage treatment schemes by implementing dry land disposal, the engineers with the Department of Public Works in New South Wales and the Department of Public Works itself-and this was when Bob Carr was the Minister for the Environment-would not allow local government to take that effluent out of the rivers, the tributaries and estuaries, and dispose of it on dry land, because they were philosophically opposed to it. They would not consider any option other than dumping that effluent into the tributaries. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I would like to bring to the House's attention a unique Australian export. This letter should have been written to Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). It says: Dear Sir It gives me great pleasure to write to you regarding the help and assistance given to me by AQIS Staff, particularly Garry Garreffa and Geoff Wood, in Perth. Since September 1994 I have been endeavouring to export frozen goat livers from Australia to Italy, and the above staff have patiently and efficiently assisted me to overcome the many frustrating obstacles encountered. The first commercial shipment flew out of Australia this month, and it is anticipated that the demand will increase significantly later in 1997. For your information an extract found only in goat livers (UK.lOl) is proving to be one of the newer cancer cures. Initial Italian trials have been very encouraging. Trials are currently being conducted in Mexico. Since the 1st January, 1997 the Italian Government has legislated that any cancer patient can be treated with UK.lOI. The advent of mad cow disease has accelerated the demand for this raw material, hence a new export for Australia. Could you please convey my thanks and appreciation of AQIS Perth's three years assistance, as mentioned above, to their superiors and your government. Yours faithfully NA Australia is well positioned to export these goat livers because we are free of the debilitating sheep and goat disease called scrapie. I congratulate Dr MCDermott, who is a leading veterinary scientist in Australia, on his initiative. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: DR JD MCDERMOTT
text: Three years ago today, on 20 March, the New Delhi statement on Tibetan freedom was released at the conclusion of the three-day world parliamentarians convention on Tibet-a gathering attended by members of parliament from 25 countries. Australia was represented at the conference by Senator Robert Hill, who was then the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Regrettably, the sentiments contained in the four-page statement continue to pertain. I call on the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to ignore the posturing of the Chinese government and raise on behalf of Australia the concerns of many that so many issues in relation to Tibet continue to remain unresolved. The reports of human rights violations, illegal detentions and environmental vandalism continue. As a demonstration of what could be a very mature and important relationship with China, the Prime Minister should feel quite comfortable in raising the Tibet issue. As part of the New Delhi statement, there were the so-called 10 commandments of Delhi. Amongst them was to encourage visits of the Dalai Lama. Last year we saw the very successful visit of the Dalai, including a visit to this parliament. Also included in that statement was the suggestion that we should target international bodies. There have been many that believe that the United Nations could do more to resolve the Tibet question. The last point made in this 10-point plan was to encourage human rights in China and at home. I believe that the Chinese government should be encouraged to sit down with the Dalai Lama and resolve the questions in Tibet. (Time expired) Employment: New South Wales Central Coast

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: DR JD MCDERMOTT
text: The federal government's handling of the Holsworthy airport issue has been deceitful and disgraceful. On 21 May 1996 the government announced a new EIS process for Sydney's second international airport which included Holsworthy as a possible site in addition to the long identified Badgerys Creek option. On that day, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) said that, despite Holsworthy being included, the government's first priority was Badgerys Creek. Yesterday, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr MCGauran) advised this House that a leaked memorandum proposing a swap of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor for an airport at Holsworthy was written in June 1996. The memorandum, which was a written to the minister just a few weeks after Mr Sharp's statement that Badgerys Creek was the government's first option, discloses that one of Minister Sharp's senior advisers was telling other government staffers that Badgerys Creek was 'dead as a viable option for the airport'. The leaked memorandum discloses that the government's EIS is a farce because it indithe cates that the government effectively has a predetermined view against Badgerys Creek and in favour of Holsworthy. Not only were the residents of St George and Sutherland misled by the government failing to disclose the Holsworthy proposal prior to the last election but they are now being further deceived by a fundamentally flawed EIS process. Advances to Income Support Recipients

Title: DR JD MCDERMOTT
text: I rise to speak briefly about the scheme that enables income support recipients to receive a $500 advance. I have invited the minister to consider reviewing the scheme perhaps with my area as a case study. The Frankston Community Support and Information Centre and the Mornington Community Advice Bureau could provide very useful on the ground advice and feedback on how the scheme is operating and whether it is meeting the longer term needs of income support recipients and the original objectives of the scheme.
