Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. First, can the Prime Minister assure the House that the reasonable alternatives the government has offered Sir Julius Chan are conditional on an absolute commitment from the Papua New Guinea government to revive the Bougainville peace process-not just a commitment in words but a commitment to concrete measures designed to get all parties to the Bougainville conflict back to negotiating table? Second, given the growing problem with mercenaries worldwide-as instanced by today's reports of ties in Zaire-will the government take up our proposal for Australia to sponsor a UN resolution calling on the international community to condemn all use of mercenaries and strengthen global efforts to eliminate the use of these forces?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question. In answer to the second part of his question, can I say that I will have a look at that. I share his distaste for the use of mercenaries. They have been a wholly sordid and unsatisfactory development in our part of the world. Can I say that the indication at present that the mercenaries may in part at least be starting to withdraw from Papua New Guinea is something that I very warmly welcome. I am sure all members of the House join me in expressing that welcome. So far as the first part of the question is concerned, can I assure the Leader of the Opposition that the reasonable alternatives I put to Sir Julius Chan last Sunday week were based upon three elements. The first element was that the mercenaries not be used in Bougainville, the second element was the disavowal of a new military offensive in Bougainville and the third element was a genuine commitment to a resumption of the peace process. So in general terms, I can answer in the affirmative to the Leader of the Opposition's question. I am sure he and his colleagues will understand that it is not really in the interests of a further satisfactory progressing of this issue for me to be any more specific. Economy

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute leading index of economic activity? Does the index support the view that economic activity will continue to strengthen, resulting in an improving environment for business?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Boothby for his question. I can the inform him that the index does support the view that economic activity will continue to strengthen, resulting in an improving environhorrific atrociment for business. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute leading index of economic activity rose one per cent in January, reinforcing an upward trend in the previous three months and bringing the smooth growth rate to around four per cent, the strongest rate of growth since October 1994. Of course, in October 1994 monetary policy was tightened at that period. The leading index is a function of a range of other indicators that feed into it which are beginning to show a picture of rising activity. For example, building approvals and housing finance approvals both increased markedly in January and there was strong growth in corporate profits. In addition, recent business surveys are suggesting increases in overtime. These are also consistent with the release this morning of the DEETYA skilled vacancy survey for February. This showed that skilled vacancies have risen in trend terms for the last five months and are now 11 per cent above the level of October 1996. They can be taken together with other leading indicators. Mr MCMullan-How do they relate to March 1996?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I know the Labor Party, from their increasingly volatile interjections, love to see the Australian economy picking up! Nothing seems to ruin their day more than the Australian economy picking up pace. ANZ job vacancies were up 1.8 per cent in February. As I said also, the other leading indicators are increased building approvals, household finance approvals and retail trade. I said that the leading index is the strongest since October 1994 which brought a monetary policy response at the end. I have also said previously that was not without its benefits in relation to keeping inflation under control. The good thing about this pick-up in activity is that it is on a very low inflation base. The other good thing about it is that in the last year we have accomplished an enormous structural change-a structural change in the Commonwealth fiscal position of $7.2 billion. So we come into this pick-up in activity not just preserving low inflation but with a structural change in relation to fiscal consolidation of $7.2 billion by this government. I regret that the Australian Labor Party fought it tooth and nail. The Australian Labor Party, with fiscal irresponsibility unseen in Australia in recent times, fought that fiscal consolidation. This government was pleased to put it in place. The structural change which we accomplished was at a time of low inflation and increasing economic growth, a matter which should be welcomed by both sides of this House.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. I am happy to let him wallow in the glory of getting the economy back almost to where it was last March. Has the Treasurer seen the report that he will at tomorrow's Premiers Conference propose a new wholesale sales tax regime to be applied to many state, territory and local government functions? Does he agree that such a proposal would be yet another breach of the government's commitment not to increase existing taxes or impose new taxes? Will the Treasurer rule out imposing this new tax on other levels of government? And while he is about it, will he also rule out any further cuts to specific purpose payments to the states?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I have not seen such a report. I have no idea what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on about, and, I suspect, nor does he. Payroll Deduction of Union Dues

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Is the minister aware of reports in today's media regarding plans by the government to cancel the payroll deduction of union dues in the Australian Public Service if unions act unreasonably in the workplace? Can the minister clarify for the benefit of the House the government's initiative on payroll deduction of union dues in the Public Service?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. As I think most honourable members would be aware, one of the most important aspects of the Workplace Relations Act is that, under part 10, we have provided for the first time an absolute guarantee for Australian workers that they have absolute freedom of choice as to whether or not they are a member of a union, so much so that we have preserved one of the items proscribed under the act in respect of unlawful termination. You cannot victimise a person because they are a member of a union. In fact, we have increased penalties against employers who victimise somebody because they exercise that choice to be a member of Taxation a union. The great debate in Australia is that those on the other side of the House do not believe that people should also have the right not to be a member of a union if that is their desire. One of the great things is that, under the Workplace Relations Act, we have abolished compulsory unionism in this country. There is no safe haven for compulsory unionism either within the state or federal jurisdictions across the country. The government, when it comes to the Australian Public Service, acts not just as a legislator but as an employer. We simply want to reinforce the provisions of the new act which came into operation on 1 January. We want to be satisfied that those members who have chosen to be members of a union within the Australian Public Service have provided us with a current and genuine authority that they wish their union dues to continue to be deducted. The system will be that we are writing to people within the APS. I have informed the unions. I spoke with them a couple of weeks ago about the policy and advised them of it. We are seeking from APS members a genuine, current, fresh authority from them to that effect. If that is what people wish to do, then, consistent with that principle of freedom of association, we are prepared to collect those union dues. We also say, as has been the case since the day we were elected, that this is a discretion ultimately in the hands of the government. We welcome and support responsible unionism where that is the choice of members. Where people are acting irresponsibly, then of course that is a discretion-namely, the capacity to collect those dues and pass them on-which we reserve unto the government. We think that is fair and reasonable. We believe that where people want to be in a union that is fair enough. We are prepared to talk with the unions who are genuinely representing the interests of their members. Most members of the APS who are in unions will see this as a very fair decision on the of the government. Tourism: Great Barrier Reef

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Robertson for his question. The government part is involved in very major reforms to help unemployed people at the present time. Yesterday the work for the dole legislation was introduced into the parliament. Of course all sides of this House will be aware of the enormous public support that there is for this legislation. In the next three months the government will be embarking on an historic reform of services for unemployed people. One billion dollars worth of services currently provided by the Commonwealth Employment Service will be tendered out. This cance for around 500,000 clients of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The tender is expected to close at the end of May. Contracts will be signed around September. This is one of the most significant social reforms that this country has seen for many years. The new system, which we believe will be a much more effective system for helping unemployed people, will be in place by the end of the year. Mr Crean interjecting

It is no wonder that will have signifi- the Australian

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

This cloning process is going on and on. We have Woolly Head here, and Dolly down there. They are clones, and they do not seem to be able to get any sense of direction whatever.

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Tourism: Great Barrier Reef

Speaker: Mr BEDDALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment. Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I have not seen any reports and do not have any information about whether or not the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has acted in the way that you suggest. But it is quite clear that government policy is that there will be a collection of a charge to meet the costs of visitation to the Great Barrier Reef. That has been accepted by a majority in this place. It is government policy. It builds on, as I said in the last answer, the decision that you took to have a charge. I might say that the member for Cunningham was involved in the committee report that recommended in part that there be such a charge. It is fair. It is equitable. There have been detailed consultations with the industry and with members about the appropriateness of the charge and how it should be proceeded with. Toxic Shock Syndrome

Speaker: Mr ENTSCH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the fact that tampons that do not comply with Therapeutic Goods Order 51 are still being sold today, some 14 months after the final date of compliance with Therapeutics Goods Order 51, which, among other things, requires all primary packaging of tampons to be clearly marked with a warning that toxic shock syndrome is a rare but serious disease that may cause death? What efforts is the government taking to remind retailers of their responsibility to conform with TG051, and what action is available to the government against those retailers who refuse to comply?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I am aware of the situation, and I thank the member for Leichhardt for alerting both me and the Therapeutic Goods Authority to it. There has been quite a deal of interest in toxic shock, and it principally relates to the third inquest into the death of a l3-year-old Mount Isa girl who died in a swimming pool in December 1994. That inquest has just concluded, and it is not proper for me to discuss that at this point in time. However, Australia manufactures or imports some 400 million tampons a year. Tampons are required to be very clean, but they are not required to be sterile. As far as I know, no country in the world, other than Japan, requires sterile tampons, and Japan only does it for imports which might have an intent other than simply safety. Toxic shock syndrome, as the honourable member said, is very rare. Its occurrence is probably fewer than one in five million women. Nonetheless, it does happen and it does have nasty consequences. Even though tampons are very safe, women do have the right to have informed consent. That is why Therapeutic Goods Order 51 was introduced by the previous government in 1995, and it was something that I, when shadow minister, supported. We were expecting there to be a bit of a changeover time of two to three months between the old tampon boxes, which had no warning, and the new boxes, but the honourable member found, on visiting a number of supermarkets in North Queensland, that there were, in a number of cases, tampons with the old box numbers. We were able to trace these. I find it disturbing that tampons manufactured in October 1993 are being sold in North Queensland in January 1997. That clearly reflects bad stock turnover and stock control. I would not want to suggest that these tampons are in any way dangerous. There is no evidence of that but, again, women do have a right to have informed consent and be aware of the small risk. At a federal level, the Therapeutic Goods Authority controls tampons and has done since 1991, but it only controls their manufacture. Australia has one large manufacturerJohnson & Johnson-which has about 60 per cent of the market. They have a national sales network which ensured, in early 1996, that there was no product left on the shelves. But smaller companies do not have a national sales network and cannot institute that measure. The Commonwealth does not control wholesaling and retailing; the states do. I am afraid that we do not have capacity to do anything there, but I will write to all state and territory health ministers and alert them to the fact that, clearly, in some parts of Australia there is poor stock control and product over three years since the date of manufacture appearing on the shelves. I will ask that they use what power they have to ensure that this does not continue. Unemployment

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, is the decision to redefine real jobs an admission that the government is finding it too hard to kick goals on the employment field? Why is the government shifting the goal posts? Is it the case that a person working 20 hours a week is regarded by the Howard government as a full-time worker? Why has the government defined part-time workers as fUll-time workers? Why has the government fiddled the figures?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: That is not a bad question from the greatest kicker of own goals, the man pledged to lead the trade union movement of Australia, who, together with the then Labor government, created the circumstances that drove over 11 per cent of the Australian population out of work-the worse since the Great Depression. That was the own goal you kicked-and you helped your former government colleagues to kick-when you, as head of the ACTU, and the then Labor government ran the affairs of this country. My advice is that the legislation to which the honourable gentleman refers does not redefine what is regarded as a part-or full time job. It merely spells out the benchmark in terms of obtaining employment options that must be reached before certain payments become payable. Veterans: Accidents in the Home

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The minister would be aware that accidents in the home, particularly bums and falls, are becoming far too common as the veterans community ages. As many of these accidents are preventable, will the minister take steps to address this problem and assist veterans and war widows to improve their health and quality of life?

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Wide Bay for his interest in the veteran community. Accidents-particularly as the member for Wide Bay highlighted-bums and falls, poor nutrition and medication misuse do cause pain and suffering to our veteran community and our war widows in this nation. They can often lead to a lengthy stay in hospital. Anecdotal evidence suggests that preventative care visits to the home of the elderly, incorporating education, advice and referral to health professionals, often lead to an improvement in the health, well-being and independence of the veterans and the elderly in our community. That is, of course, an absolute priority of this government. This government, and my portfolio in particular, will have an Australian first in this area. Incorporating research with the University of Newcastle, it will trial home based preventative care visits to the homes of veterans and war widows in metropolitan Australia and rural Australia in Queensland and New South Wales. The trial will involve approximately 1,500 veterans and war widows. I can advise the member for Wide Bay that these visits and trials are likely to include veterans and war widows in the cities of Maryborough and Hervey Bay, and in that lovely rural town, Gayndah, in his electorate. The trials, I must stress, are voluntary. That is extremely important because we will also be selecting nurses from within the community who are specially trained to visit the homes of veterans and war widows. This is extremely important because they will be able to identify, where necessary, where some of the ills which befall our veteran community are able to be prevented. It is much better to prevent an accident by taking preventative action rather than waiting for it to happen. This will create a stronger link between the doctor, the veteran and the community nurse. If we can prevent illness and injury to our veterans and war widows, we will make sure that they have better health and more independence. That is in the best interests of our veteran community. I will keep the House informed as to the results and the progress of the trials. World War II: Misappropriation of

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Recent evidence has shown that it was not only stolen Jewish gold that was misappropriated with the connivance of Swiss banks but also large amounts of money deposited in Swiss banks by the allies for prisoners of war was misappropriated by the Japanese and used in fact for their war effort. This money was deposited in the Swiss National Bank and with the connivance of the Yokohama Species Bank, now the Tokyo Mitsubishi Bank, was diverted to Japanese forces. Since it is likely that Australian money was involved in the ally deposits, does your government intend to pursue this matter and seek to recover this money? If not, why not?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will analyse the question. Merit Review Bodies: Amalgamation

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice. Is it correct, as reported by Michael Millett today's Sydney Morning Herald, that the government is looking at a radical proposal involving the amalgamation of a raft of merit review bodies including the Veterans' Review Board, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal?

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Fisher for his question. It is in fact correct that the government is actively considering such an amalgamation. That amalgamation was recommended in the Better Decisions report of the Administrative Review Council. Cabinet has agreed in principle to amalgamate the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Veterans' Review Board, the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal into a single tribunal which would be called the Administrative Review Tribunal. The amalgamation contemplated would streamline administrative structures and enhance the operations of the tribunal system. It is envisaged that separate divisions of the proposed ART would develop and maintain flexible, cost effective and non-legalistic procedures relevant to their jurisdictions. An Money interdepartmental committee comprising senior Commonwealth officers will devise a strategy for implementing the amalgamation. The basis and scope of administrative review designed to reduce the number of applications, the overall costs of merits review and excessive legalism will also be looked at. Detailed implementation of the recommendations for improvements to process and procedures of merits review tribunals contained in the Better Decisions report will also be considered. Work for the Dole

Speaker: Mr GRIFFIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I seek clarification of an aspect of the work for the dole bill and refer the Prime Minister to his minister's second reading speech yesterday when introducing the bill. Is it a fact that the wage rates for hours worked under the work for the dole scheme will be at the training award wage rate but that there will be no requirement for 20 per cent of the time to be spent in strucin tured training? Does this not mean that workers will be required to work 100 per cent of the time but be paid only 80 per cent of the award rate?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The purpose of the government's work for the dole scheme is to provide for the target group, which initially and overwhelmingly will be between the ages of 18 and 24, the opportunity to acquire some work skills in circumstances where nobody can possibly allege that those people are being exploited. I want to make it very clear that there is nothing in the legislation which in any way gives rise to charges, either direct or implied, that people are being exploited. The principle is that people are going to be properly remunerated for the time that they spend on the job. I regard that as being a proper working out of the principle of mutual obligation. The principle of mutual obligation is that we look after people who cannot get a job and it is only fair and reasonable that they do something in return. Literacy Testing

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I draw the minister's attention to an article in today's Australian in which Frank Devine says, 'We need standardised testing if we are to end illiteracy.' I ask the minister: what is the progress to date of the implementation of national standardised testing for literacy? Is the minister aware of teacher opposition to the literacy testing program? Can the minister advise the reasoning behind the introduction of a national literacy test?

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. No-one in the parliament, I venture to say, has done more to draw attention to the literacy needs of young people than the member for La Trobe.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He chaired the committee.

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He chairs the House standing committee. Indeed, he is one of the authors of the minority report, brought down by that committee some four years ago, which drew attention to the need to test all young people in the early years of schooling in order to establish their literacy needs. The historic agreement that I was able to reach with the states and territories last for a national literacy and numeracy plan which specifically addresses the needs of young people in the early years of schooling can in many ways be seen as a culmination of the work that the member for La Trobe has been engaged in. I am ready before this House to acknowledge my indebtedness to him for his work. A very key part of this plan is that all students should be tested against national standards or national benchmarks. We will know for the first time whether or not the policies that have been put in place to teach young people to read and write are in fact working and we will know where the greatest progress is being made in the states and territories around this country. I have to say that it was deeply disappointing to read the remarks of the federal president of the Australian Education Union, who described this decision, which has been hailed, I think it is fair to say, around the country, as 'one of the most disappointing decisions ever for quality education'. The Australian Education Union is, of course, the body which gave the Labor Party its education policy. It is because the Labor Party has followed the dictates of the Australian Education Union and the teacher unions for 13 years that we have the current situation where 30 per cent of 14-year-olds cannot read properly. We have seen the opposition of the unions to the learning assessment program in Victoria, which has the overwhelming support of parents. We have seen the continuing opposition of the unions to testing in New South Wales, where the situation is in fact very little better than in Victoria and where the union has banned the basic skills tests. This government is committed to providing Australian parents with the information they need to determine whether their children are gaining successful education and building up the skills that they need for life. It does teachers no service, it does parents no service and it certainly does children no service for the education unions of this country to stick their heads in the sand and try to keep parents Friday and the community in the dark about the performance of Australia's schools. Unemployment

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, yesterday you quoted from my speech at the National Press Club on 14 August 1991, so you will not mind my quoting from a press conference you gave just six days earlier when you said: It is my opinion that we will never in my lifetime ... go below an unemployment level of five per cent. Prime Minister, do you stand by your statement that a five per cent unemployment rate will not be achieved in your lifetime?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I have no reason to doubt fOf a moment the veracity of what I said then. Let me repeat what I have said repeatedly since I became the Prime Minister of Australia. That is, I will do all in my power to implement policies to reduce the level of unemployment in this country, but I am not going to hitch myself to a particular target as Prime Minister. I have said that repeatedly, and I repeat it again. I want to make it very plain on behalf of the government that we are absolutely committed to policies that will bring down unemployment, but we are not going to get ourselves attached to a target. While on the subject of employment, the member for Hotham invites me, because he goes back a littleMr Crean-No, you went back.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No, you went back first, so I am going to go back again. Perhaps the member for Hotham will remember giving an ABC interview on 4 February 1992 after the closure of a car plant which was located in the electorate of Hotham. He gave this interview on 4 February 1992. So in the context of the member for Hotham seeking my views on jobs, let me remind the House what the member for Hotham had to say, and it sits rather at odds with the crocodile tears he and his colleagues have been shedding in recent times about manufacturing industry in Australia. This is what he had to say: Now, the Button car plan has done that for the automotive industry. This is what he said to say: It was always recognised that there were going to be job losses. That is what he said. When he was a minister in the government, he was saying, 'You've got to have job losses,' and now he is taking every little debating point he can. He said: It was always recognised that there were going to be job losses. Whether it's closure of plants or job restructuring, there have been significant job losses in the automotive industry and that has been accepted as a necessary part of making the industry competitive.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order, which goes to relevance. Is it relevant for the Prime Minister to point these out in relation to the question that was asked of him and not mention the fact that that same Button car plan produced a 400 per cent increase in exports?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No, we are not going to debate the issue. There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: -It gets even better. On the World Today on 28 February 1991, this is what he had to say, and this is a real peader: I think that many in the media do not appreciate it that all tariffs did was to make us look inward. All the tariffs did was to protect local production. There was no basis upon which there was intemational competition to drive innovation. The absolute core of the interview was when the interviewer said: So you and Paul Keating are now at one on the direction of industry policy? And he replied, 'Yep.' So, can I say that over the last few days the Labor Party have been desperately trying to de-Keatingise themselves. They have been trying to get rid of the ghost and here we have the arch hypocrite of the lot because he said 'Yep,' when asked, 'So you and Paul Keating are now at one on the direction of industry policy?' I do not think the workers in the car industry in South Australia take any notice of you. You promised you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank, and you did. You promised you would not privatise Qantas, and you did. You are promising something on manufacturing industry, and they are not even listening. Traineeships and Apprenticeships

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is also to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The minister would be aware of the employment needs of Melbourne's outer eastern suburbs and that the decision to locate a one-stop apprenticeship shop in Ringwood has been well received. Can the minister inform the people in my electorate of Deakin how the implementation of one-stop shops is progressing and what effect they will have on the availability of traineeships and apprenticeships?

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Deakin for his question and I acknowledge his very strong commitment to the young people in his electorate. The government is streamlining arrangements for apprenticeships and traineeships, and one of the most important initiatives in this regard has been the establishment of one-stop apprenticeship and traineeship shops. Agreement has been reached by the government with all the states and territories to establish 18 demonstration projects which will combine Commonwealth and state entry level training functions. Three projects have already commenced-in Cairns, in the Australian Capital Territory, and in Launceston-and the rest will be opening over the next month. I hope that I will be able to be present in the member's electorate to assist in opening the one-stop shop in his electorate. There will be four such shops in New South Wales, four in Victoria, three in Queensland, two in Western Australia, two in South Australia, two in Tasmania and one in the Australian Capital Territory. These shops are part of a very substantial simplification of the training system which the government is putting in place. This has been necessary because of the extremely complex and bureaucratic nature of the system under the Labor Party. What we tragically saw under the previous government was an emphasis on short-term training programs which did not lead on to real jobs and the lowest number of apprentices and trainees as a proportion of the work force for three decades. This government is determined to revive the apprenticeship system, to produce quality training for young Australians, and this initiative is a very important step in this direction. Automotive Industry

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is again to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports of yesterday's speech by South Australian Premier, John Olsen? Does he agree with the Premier's view that: If the Productivity Commission's program were accepted by Canberra the local automotive industry would not survive. And another quote: And I doubt the federal Liberal government would survive being the executioner of our automotive industry. Prime Minister, will you be the executioner, or will you back Labor's plan to export Australia's cars rather than Australian jobs?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Which Labor plan? The plan you had when you were in government or the plan you have when you are in opposition? Your problem on this-and it is your leader's problem on this and it is the problem that all of you have-is that the people who deserted you in March of last year deserted you because they no longer believed you. And they did not believe you because you promised things and then ratted on them after you got re-elected. You promised the Australian people that you would not privatise Qantas. You promised the Australian people that you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank. Your former leader wrote a letter to the members of the Bank Employees Union promising across his heart and on a stack of bibles that you would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank-and what did you do when got re-elected? You privatised the Commonwealth Bank. And it is burnt across the brain of every defected Labor supporter who voted for us in March that you were a group of people that could no longer be trusted. Can I make it very clear to the House and to the people who are employed in the motor manufacturing industry in Australia that I have said repeatedly that this government remains strongly committed to the maintenance of a motor vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia. As to the response that we deliver to the recommendations of the Productivity Commission, I might gently point out to everybody who comments on this issue that we do not have the final recommendations of the Productivity Commission yet and, until we have the final recommendations of the Productivity Commission, we will not be amusing ourselves with the little games that are being played opposite. That is all you can do-you can play little games on this subject. When we get the report of the Productivity Commission, we will take a decision that is in the interests of all of Australian people. We will naturally have regard to the interests of people who work in the motor manufacturing industry. We will not gloat about the impact of change, as you did when you were in government. We will not treat people as commodities to be shifted around, as you did when you were in governmentOpposition members-Oh!

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Oh, you express indignation. Have you forgotten what happened to manufacturing employment when you ran Australia? Have you forgotten that in 13 years you drove unemployment to a post-Depression high? Have you forgotten that it went over 11 per cent? Have you forgotten the devastation that your policies and those of Joan Kirner and John Bannon and Brian Burke caused to the economy not only of Australia but to the economies of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia? You come into this House now and parade yourselves as the born-again believers in the battlers of Australia. The truth is that you ratted on them, you deserted them, and that is why they threw you out. Workplace Relations Act

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education-excuse me-the Minister for Industrial Relations. Minister, you will recall participating a recent workplace relations seminar in my electorate hosted by the Peninsula T AFE and the Monash University's Key Centre for Industrial Relations. What is the government doing to inform employees and employers of the new opportunities for better pay for better work, enhanced productivity and for improving the balance between work and home responsibilities under the Workplace Relations Act?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for his question. I am not sure whether I am elated or insulted-and that is no disrespect to my colleague the member for Goldstein. In fact, there is a lot of activity that the government is involved in in telling people about the Workplace Relations Act and the opportunities it provides to both employers and employees. The member for Dunkley and I were the both at a seminar the other day, and there were a lot of people there-a lot of small business people. I know that the member himself is getting out and about in the community. He is fighting for small business people; he is getting the message out to people about the opportunities, particularly for small business, because we see tremendous opportunities for small business in this. The government is doing its bit. The Australian workplace agreement being an individual agreement that you can have at work without a union and without the commission, which is fair to employees and good for business, is an historic change which we are keen to see. We have opened the Office of the Employment Advocate in the last week or so. There are advertisements in the national press. Mr Bevis-For the whole state.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I warn the member for Brisbane.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There is a hotline you can ring to obtain the information kit. That information kit contains information for employees and information for employers. There has been a huge response to it, Prime Minister. Within the first few hours we had 500 requests for the kit and I think as of the last couple of days we have had 2,600 requests. We have even had one of the opposition in member's staff ring for a copy of the kit. So the employer organisations are backing up what we are doing. They are working hard with seminars. The National Farmers Federation is working hard. We have had some very interesting reports of people who are keen to take up the option of AW As and we are encouraging them. The Office of the Employment Advocate is slowly building up its numbers. It is there to help people and to provide people with this opportunity. Lastly, it is not only the member for Dunkley who is doing a great job but also other members. I was in the electorate of the member for Makin the other day. There is a lot of interest in it. I was with the member for Griffith the other day. He is pushing hard. We are looking forward to a good year of providing a lot of opportunities for small business to create jobs.
