Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Last week the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) claimed credit for improvements under his government in the conduct of question time. He claimed, with complete justification, that question time was no longer the farce that it undoubtedly became under his predecessor. Although debatable, the Prime Minister also seemed to imply that what now prevails in this place is the epitome of parliamentary reform. In returning to a time honoured approach to question time prior to the aberration created by Mr Keating, I put it to the House that it hardly constitutes reform. It is the only one that goes any way towards improving the relevance of members in the conduct of proceedings in this House. The wide-ranging changes promised to achieve that end have yet to materialise. In some ways, the influence of this House on the executive has diminished. Ministers responsible for legislation rarely attend second reading debates. The responses of ministers who deign to sum up second reading debates-which are almost as rare--demonstrate that they mostly have not even monitored debate on their office television sets. To few ministers who do not offend in the manner described, I apologise. Quite often, despite the presence of advisers, technical matters raised during debate, particularly in the detailed hearing stages, either ignored completely or answered inadequately. Then there is the practice-prevalent under the previous government and almost the rule with the coalition-{)f a raft of government amendments to legislation already before the House arriving sometimes only a matter of hours before the bill or bills are to be debated. Is it any wonder that so much of legislation passed is subsequently found to be defective in one respect or another? These practices certainly do not enhance the relevance of this parliament vis-a-vis executive government. Nor do practices which the government observes in the conduct of business before the Main Committee go any way towards bettering our relevance. Up there, only the most conscientious ministers put in an appearance. The government rosters chairmen of committees to witness proceedings on its behalf. Those chairmen are not even chairman of the relevant committee-just any old chairman will do!

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Yes, but, of course, they are not authorised to and cannot respond to the concerns raised by members in debate. It boils down to this: the only improvement in parliamentary procedures under this government is to be found at the one time during the day that the Prime Minister is in attendance. So, while the Prime Minister can be justly proud of his efforts to improve question time, conduct of other business of the House leaves very much to be desired. Electorate of Paterson: Traffic Conditions

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Withstanding the test of time, going back to the early 1980s, Rutherford residents within my electorate of Paterson may soon see green rather than amber or red over the need for safer local roads. Last month, I those publicly announced my commitment to seek funding from the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr John Sharp, to deliver on the long-mooted requests by local Rutherford residents for urgent are attention to be given to the intersection at Arthur Street and the New England Highway, and calling for the construction of pedestrian traffic lights. A similar traffic hazard also confronts residents and motorists at nearby Alexandra Street. These intersections and general traffic conditions around the Rutherford area pose a stark reminder that words and more words, traffic study upon traffic study, and further community consultation can drag on for years and years, without a hole being dug or a RTA surveyor in sight. This reminder is etched in the memories of both long-term Rutherford residents and local business people within the burgeoning Rutherford shopping precinct. The commitment and drive of Mr and Mrs Lloyd Gregory has been something to behold. They have lobbied up hill and down dale for a better and safer deal for local pedestrians and motorists for many years now. I hope to make their efforts seem worthwhile in the months ahead. I note, too, people such as Lyndon MCLeod, who runs the local family pharmacy at Rutherford, Tom and Marie Bullen of Bullens Supermarkets, Ian Turner with his newsagency, and Rotarian Arthur Dawn, who has, incidentally, just been awarded the Paul Harris Fellow Award, are just a few Rutherford residents who are keen to see the light finally for a safe intersection at Arthur Street. To my way of thinking, Rutherford shopping centre now has the unfair distinction of being one of the largest shopping areas of its kind not to have a working set of traffic signals to help regulate traffic and better pedestrian access to shoppers. That has got to change. The situation is even more disturbing when the very popular Maitland City Bowling Club, and parents and young children and teenagers utilising the nearby neighbourhood centre and child-care centre in Arthur Street, as well as Rutherford High School, are putting more and more pressure on the intersection. In fact, upon the public statement last month over my commitment to concentrate on lobbying for federal funding, this pressing road issue has again been raised to the prominence it has long deserved. Indeed, I am very pleased that, on this pressing local roadworks issue, Maitland City Council, which has gained some notoriety for some of the decisions emanating from its chamber in the last year, is 100 per cent behind the Arthur Street lights option, as outlined in their 1996 traffic study. Its own studies found that upwards of 155 pedestrians and cyclists per hour were crossing the highway during peak periods within the vicinity of Arthur Street. The federal government is now awaiting the outcome of a joint Maitland City Council and state RTA study of traffic management needs of the New England Highway at Rutherford for consideration of whether additional highway upgrading could occur. Stage I of the traffic management plan for the New England Highway between Regent Street and Dunkley Street has been completed, but more work was considered necessary on traffic solutions for the stretch between Dunkley Street and Wollombi Road, including pedestrian lights at Arthur Street. My fight for safer traffic conditions along the New England Highway, be it for Rutherford, Metford or East Maitland residents, will continue. My full support for a major upgrade of the Arthur Street intersection at Rutherford is part and parcel of that. A shopping precinct of this size, which underwent further expansion in 1995, needs a set of traffic signals to regulate pedestrian and vehicle traffic. That is an issue which my transport minister will be made well aware of. I believe there is real scope for work to take place to install a set of traffic lights, and I will be urging the minister to examine council's position and the state RTA's position on the matter. Unlike the years and years that have passed by without the former federal government or the former Labor representatives representing Rutherford residents addressing the issue or coming to any solution, I am downright determined to do the opposite and actually deliver. I have taken the case for Rutherford residents right up to the minister, and I have an inkling that he is listening to their concerns. The federal transport minister, Mr John Sharp, has responded to my request by confirming that he is waiting on the traffic management study from council, before committing federal dollars to any further upgrade. Arthur Street, as the main thoroughfare for the local shopping precinct, bowling club, high school and child-care facilities at Rutherford, has been long overdue-since the mid-1980s-for consideration of new road works. Let's face it: name a shopping centre larger than Rutherford's that does not have effective and safe access for both motorists and pedestrians. For people like the Gregory's of Rutherford, their red-light wait of some 15 years for a solution may soon tum green. Sales Tax Relief

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: No wonder the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is claiming that he is losing so much weight. It is not speed walking, it is speed talking that is trimming him down. Good luck to him. It is said that if you live long enough you will see and hear everything. Even at my tender years I am getting to that point with this piece of correspondence from the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). It is a letter that has been written to Neil Hammond of Ferny Creek, Victoria concerning the fact that earlier this year Mr Hammond's house was unfortunately burnt down in the Victorian bushfires. He wrote a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) requesting some relief for the reconstruction of his house-a temporary sales tax exemption on the building materials. That letter was sent to the Prime Minister on 27 January. A response did not arrive from the Prime Minister. It was sent on to the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who in tum sent this minor request on to the Assistant Treasurer. A letter addressed to Mr Hammond came back on 7 March and I believe it deserves to be written into the full record of the parliament and the Hansard. It states: The Assistant Treasurer has asked methat is, Virginia Lo Pilato, the adviser on taxationto respond to your letter. I sympathise with the situation that now faces you and your family. However, the Government receives many requests for reductions in tax burdens. To agree to individual requests would often only have a small impact on the Budget. However, if all of the requests were to be granted it would increase the budget deficit by billions of dollars. Such a blowout in the deficit would be unacceptable, as it would place pressure on interest rates to rise (thereby increasing unemployment and reducing economic growth) and would reduce national savings (and could therefore further increase Australia's foreign debt). I trust this information will be of assistance to you. Yours sincerely Virginia Lo Pilato Adviser (Taxation) The information is of no assistance to Mr Hammond. It is a letter of a mean spirited, mealy-mouthed government that does not have the common sense to respond to a request for compassion in sensible terms. There is no sensible response here. It is a response of the absurd. It is theatre of the absurd to say to Mr Hammond that his minor request for a concession on sales tax to help rebuild his home that had been burnt down will blowout the budget deficit by billions of dollars, will send up interest rates, will increase unemployment, will reduce economic growth, will reduce national savings and could further increase Australia's foreign debt. The minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), should have a word with his brother about this standard of absurdity coming out of his office. I have seen some economics in my day but never the economics of chaos theory. This is like saying that if a butterfly flaps its wings in Brazil there will be an earthquake in Western Australia. It is like going back to the old domino theory used in economics. Instead of having the downward flow of communism into Australia, it is the downward flow of national bankruptcy: if a fellow receives a taxation concession to rebuild a house that was burnt down in a bushfire it will send the country broke. That is to say that if Mr Hammond sneezes Australia's 17 million people will catch colds. The office of the Assistant Treasurer is saying that if he builds his house one day the next day the IMP and the World Bank will be knocking on his door to blame him for national bankruptcy. This is a response of the absurd. If a government cannot give a serious response to a family and a citizen who has suffered under the very sad circumstances of having their house burnt down then they should give no response. If they cannot give a serious response in a compassionate situation it is better to say nothing. What sort of government is so mean spirited and absurd that they cannot write back in proper terms to Mr Hammond giving him a sensible response. Instead of having Costelloomics, we have got chaos theory in the economics of government policy, we have the domino theory-that one person's small taxation concession on building materials will send the country broke-we have Mr Hammond sneezing and the nation catching colds and we have him being told that if he builds his house one day the IMF and the World Bank will knock on his door the next and say that he has sent the country broke. This is a government that is mean spirited across the board. It cannot even come up with legitimate, sound reasons to justify that set of attitudes. It has to go into the absurd. If this is the best that the Assistant Treasurer and his office can do, then they will be headed the way of Senator Short not too long from now and off overseas where they belong. Chronic Fatigue Syndrome

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am particularly pleased this evening that the honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) is in the chamber because I hope what I have to say he will agree with. I want to raise once again an issue not only as the member for Groom but also as the patron of a local community support group for those affected by myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome, a potentially disabling and chronic condition affecting the immune and central nervous systems. There is no known single cause, although for mallY it may be a viral trigger. Some patients may have a sudden onset whilst for others it may be a slow and gradual process with no easily identifiable trigger. It can vary greatly in severity and duration. There is no specific diagnostic test. It is a complex illness and the ·list of symptoms can be extensive and profound in the more severe cases. Current research suggests that a dysfunction of the immune system and the central nervous system is involved. The complexity of the illness means that the prognosis can be very difficult to predict. Some patients will make slow and gradual progress over several years to a full recovery. The majority will make variable progress with relapses which may be severe and prolonged. They may reach 70 to 80 per cent of their former functions. Others remain severely disabled with little progress, needing a lot of help with their personal needs. A smaller percentage may deteriorate and be bed bound for much of the time. Peak incidence appears to be in the 20 to 40 years age group with a slight predominance to females and cases, unfortunately, involving young children are increasing. Clearly, it is a very real and for many a very debilitating illness. The consequences of living with ME for the sufferer, the carer and the whole family unit need to be understood. I again take the opportunity to pay particular tribute to two pioneering local Toowoo mba women, Joan Sheath and Lyn Wilson, both as sufferers and as support group leaders, without whose persistent efforts the community group would not be what it is today. I am pleased also that the minister and the medical profession are now starting to do something substantive about the problem and its associated research. I also welcome Australia's active participation in International CFS Awareness Day last year. Furthermore, I am pleased that a working group has been established under the auspices of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians with the aim of developing clinical practice guidelines for the assessment and for the treatment of CFS. The working group has received a grant from the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services to develop and distribute the guidelines to all medical practitioners in Australia. This is a landmark development in CFS clinical management. The major task of the working group is to evaluate the rapidly growing body of scientific literature on CFS and to make recommendations to medical practitioners and to the community. The guidelines will provide a major resource for all concerned and will help to dispel much unfounded speculation and misinformation currently provided. A draft document is expected to be circulated to all interested parties for comment by the middle of 1997, and the finalised guidelines will be published as a supplement to the Medical Journal of Australia later this year. In making my final comment, can I say that I hope that we have left behind unreasonable perceptions that this condition-that is, CFS-is a condition of the mind rather than of the body. It is undoubtedly a debilitating illness which we cannot and must not ignore. Aboriginal Reconciliation

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Grayndler) (5.45 p.m.)I rise tonight in the adjournment debate to speak about the reconciliation process leading up to the Australian Reconciliation Convention, which is to be held from 26 to 28 May 1997 at the World Congress Centre in Melbourne. It is significant that this is being some 30 years after the referendum which actually made our indigenous people proper and full citizens of this country and which addressed the outrageous racist history of this nation, which some would like to paper over. I would like to commend the reconciliatiC'n process tonight to all parliamentarians and, indeed, to all Australians because it is an issue which is important for all of us as a nation. It has never been more important, particularly given the climate of intolerance which has been fostered since 2 March 1996. In particular, we all sit in this chamber with the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), who has stated that she would not represent Aboriginal Australians. That is an outrageous comment and one which I do not think would have been tolerated had she mentioned any other group other than our most oppressed group, indigenous people. The chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Patrick Dodson, has stated that 'to effect deep and lasting change in this country, reconciliation has to be a people's movement'. To this end, Australians for Reconciliation have worked hard all around the country with community groups and individuals at the local level. Their activities have been very much in the social justice tradition of thinking globally but acting locally. Reconciliation is a global issue. Its anti-racism message is one that must be taken seriously if we are to combat the narrow, rednecked views of the outspoken minority because it is still the case that indigenous Australians suffer from a great level of discrimination. I am pleased that the Labor Party has put as our representative on the council the member for Banks (Mr Melham), the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. I think that it is unfortunate that the government does not have the Racism Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) on the council. The representative of the government, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), is no doubt someone who is committed to the improvement of the lot of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. It is no reflection on him whatsoever, as I am sure there are many held on the other side of the House who are committed to the reconciliation process and I congratulate them for that. But, nonetheless, it sends a very bad message that the minister is not represented on the council. Also, when I heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on radio this morning, it struck me once again that he is a very good performer on radio and knows how to address his audience, but there were two sorts of addresses to the audience. When he spoke about native title, he said, 'I want to address a message directly to the farmers, and I say to you that I will represent your interests.' He spoke to them directly, but when he spoke about indigenous people, it was indirect. He was not speaking to them. There was no, 'And I say to Aboriginal Australians, I actually think that I am going to uphold your rights as well.' The fact that you have a campaign from some people in this parliament to extinguish native title is an outrageous attack on all of us, and I wish those in the government who have a more progressive and enlightened view on these issues the best of luck in combating it. In terms of the racism issue, as well tonight I wish to draw people's attention towards an ongoing community campaign against racism against indigenous Australians and, indee-, against racism wherever it exists: On 12 Ap-l there will be yet another rally In Sydney In Hyde Park against racism. It is being organised by community groups, by churches, by people who are concerned about the increasing level of intolerance. That, as part of the process of the lead-up to the reconciliation convention in May, is something that all of us should participate in in our local communities and all of us should encourage.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I have received the following letter from a constituent of mine, Ms Lara Stevenson, which I would like to bring to the attention of the Australian people. It begins: Dear Mr Hockey, I am writing to you as a twenty year old female who is concerned with a problem in our society, which I believe has gone beyond our control. DRUG ABUSE. I have never taken much time to deal with issues such as drug and alcohol abuse because it rarely concerned myself or family and friends, and I am not a person who is out to 'save the wo-ld'. I am just an ordinary girl who cannot belIeve how available, cheap and widely used hard drugs are becoming. Since the universities and schools have been on their summer break I am finding that I cannot go out on a Saturday night without somebody telling me they are on the 'best high' due to taking speed or ecstasy. When I attended high school there was always a group of people who smoked marijuana, whether it was everyday or only on weekends, I had a firm belief that they would "grow out of it" and were only experimenting. These people hav- - ow ,tu.rneto hard chemicals to get a more excltmg high. Unfortunately it is no longer a minority group taking chemicals. from what I have observed for myself 'pot' is boring so everybody has now decided that ecstasy and speed are the way to go. This habit has been justified to me by many people, I will give you some of these examples; : Cheaper than a night out drinking. ($30-$60) . Gives you a boost of energy and therefore you can dance all night. . You don't get a hangover. . You don't get hungry. . You lose weight. Admittedly twenty year olds should be old enough and responsible enough to make their own d-ci­ sions, however once someone feels the first exhilarating hit from a line of speed or an 'eccy', they want that feeling again and although they don't realise, they're already mildly addicted. It. affe.cts their way of thinking, and they no longer thmk like responsible twenty year olds. This is not hearsay, I was at a BBQ yesterday and heard one of my friends say exactly this. I work for News Limited, and I was working on The Daily Telegraph news desk the day Anna Wood died from taking an ecstasy overdose. Believe me, it scared all of us. Many people Drugs thought that The Telegraph was making an example of Anna Wood and that it was only a good story. Yes, it was a good story, because with Anna's parents and friends, the Telegraph tried to educate people on the dangers of MDMA. I originally thought Anna's death would frighten people and deter many from taking drugs, it has done the opposite, people think they are immune to side effects and even death. We think the drug problem is confined to Kings Cross, Oxford Street and Cabramatta but it isn't. I was at a nightclub on Sydney's North Shore on New Years Eve, when two fifteen year old girls and their friends approached me, I was their babysitter some time ago. Imagine my surprise to see these young girls in the nightclub and then telling me they were all on ecstasy and wasn't it great. They assumed that because many people in the nightclub were drinking water and dancing they must have been on drugs also. I realise that there will always be a drug problem in our society and there is only so much a government can do. Believe me I can go out dancing and have a great time with the best of them and I love going out with my friends. But how many more deaths, brain damage, accidents and drug overdoses do we have to see before people start to realise that it could be them next? The purpose of this letter is to te.1l you, if you didn't already know, how severe thiS problem has become, and to ask you if there is a possibility of educating young people on the dangers of drug abuse. Why does education have to stop when we leave school? Most people start using hard drugs when they leave school, they're working so therefore they can afford it. I know of two people who use their AUSTUDY money to pay for drugs and alcohol, is this fair? In the end they're just hurting themselves. The television commercials for drink driving are so effective, they shock and scare people. Is this the only way to get through to our friends? I am prepared to help in any possible way, there is only so much one person can do. I that a new drug education scheme and tougher penalties for drug pushers and users be introduced. If it means saving one persons life or another persons sanity shouldn't we do it? Lara Stevenson Government Cutbacks

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to draw the attention of the House-and in particular the attention of those members opposite-to something that they are very aware of, which is the fact that our offices are being inundated by people with problems. Those Australians who thought this was going to be a government to make them comfortable and relaxed are now finding out just the opposite. We are finding out that the cutback in government services has meant staff in government departments are not cop in g either. I just want to go through some of the examples of the kinds of problems that are coming on a regular basis. A number of people have been in tears when they have spoken to me both on the phone and at my office. The change to social security to become a more efficient system has meant that various offices have actually stopped the system of queuing by number, where they could talk to a departmental officer at a cubicle. People are now required to stand in a line and be dealt with one after the other. I was speaking with a woman this week who spent 20 minutes in line. The woman is 65 years of age, with osteoporosis, but there were no chairs available so she could not sit down. And if she had sat down, she would have lost her spot in the queue anyhow. While she was in the queue she could hear the people ahead telling the officer their business. When it got to her tum, she did not want her affairs to be heard by all the people behind her, but that was what was required. My staff have now dealt with the woman in some detail. The fact is that this woman did not have a problem. Incidentally, she had already rung up earlier and tried.to make an appointment. The current waiting time is three weeks. She felt that she had a problem with but her affairs which may have meant that she propose was frauding. She was extremely anxious, . which was why she wanted to be able to talk to the officer face to face. When my staff then dealt with her in some depth, of course she had no problem. But now she hasbecause she is now very upset and very ill. And this is the kind of damage being done by those opposite who are talking about people being comfortable and relaxed. A gentleman who came into my office on Monday afternoon has two daughters are on Austudy. He has a bankrupt company, but it is a company which means he goes through the actual means test. His wife has been told by her doctor that she can no longer work on the application because her illness, induced by trying to sort out and deal with the Austudy claims, is such that she can no longer cope. So now he is doing it instead. The fact is that these people are on benefits. They have two daughters-one at university, one at school. They are uncertain. Their Austudy has currently been refused. A young woman came in who has an income of $20,000 a year. That got converted to $116,000 a year. She had her year planned out till suddenly she was told she was not eligible for Austudy. The fact is that those who are not eligible for Austudy are eligible for social security. And what is happening? They are being forced to take it. The savings that are supposedly being made are not going to be available because it will be another part of the budget where the spending will come from. We are going to see a cut and a saving in Austudy but, equally, we are going to see an increase in the number of people on benefits. Turning to benefits, people put in their income declarations on a regular basis--every month, every fortnight-and it is absolutely exact, absolutely accurate. There is now a computer error. So one constituent this week now has a debt of $4,000. The department said, 'Look, I'm sorry. It is our mistake, but pay up.' These are people with no money. The government will trumpet this as a saving-'Here we are. We have caught some frauds. We have saved some money.' Who are they saving it off? People who are impoverished. You government members all know this because I have no doubt that you are all getting the same problems and in the same volume, if not more so. Because you are in government, I do not doubt that people will be coming to you thinking you can help. I also know how powerless you are, as your constituents are finding out. And what is tragic is that you have done so little to make any difference. Dr Kemp-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Within broad guidelines government, Catholic and independent education authorities in each State and Territory are responsible for the detailed administration of the Literacy Program. The Commonwealth does not collect information on the amount of Disadvantaged Schools Program (DSP) funding received by individual schools. In 1996 seventeen (17) primary schools, ten (10) high schools and two (2) special schools in the government sector received funding under the Disadvantaged Schools Program (DSP). No nongovernment schools received support under this element. CAPITAL GRANTS TO NON-GOVERNMENT School Bethel Christian Academy Clare Catholic High School NA Under new arrangements for the structure and delivery of Commonwealth programs for schools which apply from 1997, funding previously provided under DSP is included within the Government's broader new Literacy Program. In 1997 it is expected that there will be eighteen (18) primary schools, ten (10) high schools and two (2) special schools in the government sector receiving funding in 1997 under the DSP portion of the Literacy Program. (2) Did the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the NSW Department of Urban Affairs and Planning jointly prepare a nomination of the Sydney Opera House and its harbour setting for inscription on the World Heritage List by the Government of Australia in 1996. (3) If so, (a) did the property nominated include the Sydney Opera House, the island of Fort Denison, the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the waterways of Sydney Harbour to the mean high water mark from Robinson's Point and Mrs Macquarie's Point in the east to Blues Point and Dawes Point in the west and (b) did the nomination state that the property illustrates the themes of twentieth century architecture and the cultural heritage of Australia, both of which are under-represented on the World Heritage List and that the inclusion of the property would assist in creating a more universally representative list. (4) Did the Australian Government lodge the nomination with the World Heritage Committee on 1 July 1996 when it lodged the nomination of Australia's Sub-Antarctic Islands; if not, why not. (5) Are preparations being made to lodge the nomination by 1 July 1997 in time for the World Heritage Bureau and the World Heritage Committee to consider it in 1998; if not, why not. Mr Warwick Smith-The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Yes (2) The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the NSW Department of Urban Affairs and Planning cooperated, over the period of 1995 and 1996, in an assessment of the values of the Sydney Opera House in its Harbour Setting and the preparation of a World Heritage nomination. Preparation of the draft nomination was the responsibility of the then New South Wales Department of Urban Affairs and Planning. The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories was represented on a steering committee of officials which oversaw the work. The Commonwealth Government has not lodged that nomination with the World Heritage Committee. (3)(a) Yes (3)(b) Yes (4) No. The Commonwealth Government did not receive the nomination from the New South Wales Government until 26 July 1996, which was too late to allow submission to the World Heritage Committee for consideration that year. (5) The Commonwealth Government has decided not to forward the nomination to the World Heritage Committee at this time. The Prime Minister wrote, in a letter of 19 August 1996 to the New South Wales Premier, that he would wish to ensure complete accord between Governments over funding and management arrangements, if a nomination is to proceed. Uncertainties are raised by the New South Wales nomination of the building in its harbour setting, particularly the difficulty of establishing satisfactory management arrangements in a dynamic urban setting which includes a working harbour. Accordingly, the Commonwealth has decided that its limited resources for World Heritage matters are best devoted to the nominations we have in progress (notably the Subantarctic Islands), the assessments we have under way and the proper management of the eleven properties already on the World Heritage List. Title: SCHOOLS IN THE ELECTORATE OF CHIFLEY
